story:
in breve...

«il Lettore di Fantasia» è una rivista gratuita che pubblica narrativa fantastica, retribuendo gli autori secondo una chiara tariffa a cartella grazie alle inserzioni pubblicitarie e a campagne come questa.

La rivista esiste sia in formato cartaceo che digitale; siamo fermamente convinti che la carta sia ancora un importante supporto di lettura.

Il nostro scopo è diffondere la letteratura fantastica e aiutare gli autori a crescere e ad affermarsi.

cosa facciamo

L'attività della rivista si può riassumere in alcuni punti chiave:

  • pubblichiamo narrativa di qualità; retribuendo gli autori possiamo essere altamente selettivi e garantire ai nostri lettori un elevato livello dei testi pubblicati
  • diffondiamo la lettura in generale e la narrativa fantastica in particolare; grazie alla distribuzione gratuita e al doppio formato cartaceo e digitale riusciamo a raggiungere una grande quantità di lettori
  • informiamo i lettori; la nostra pagina Facebook, seguita da migliaia di utenti, è una miniera di informazioni per chi ama la lettura e il mondo del fantastico in generale; segnaliamo autori, libri, eventi e notizie accuratamente selezionate
  • aiutiamo chi ci aiuta; chiunque abbia un locale, una libreria, un negozio di giochi, o una qualsiasi attività aperta al pubblico può richiedere gratuitamente delle copie della rivista da distribuire ai propri clienti, in cambio di visibilità sul nostro sito e sulla nostra pagina Facebook

gli obiettivi

Questa campagna è nata con l'obiettivo principale di aiutarci ad aumentare il numero di pagine della rivista ed espandere la rete di distribuzione per raggiungere sempre nuovi lettori.

Aumentare le pagine significa riuscire a pubblicare più testi, a dare spazio a più autori e illustratori, e ad offrire ai lettori un prodotto ancora più interessante,

Aumentare la diffusione della rivista significa incentivare la lettura e aprire a un pubblico sempre maggiore le porte del fantasy e della fantascienza italiani.

story:
~ We are so honored and moved by the amazing support of our extended community in helping us to reach and exceed our goal of $750 for The Art of Life After Project! We are truly amazed, surprised, and appreciative.

Although we met our initial benchmark, we are continuing to fundraise in order to increase the funding to compensate our amazing community partners and artists in a way that truly acknowledges the power of the work that they do. If you feel moved to still donate, all donations will absolutely be put to positive use and if you cannot donate, please support us by sharing our campaign.

Again, we truly appreciate and value your support from the bottom of our hearts.  <3 Mattie & Alicia ~

Short Summary

The inspiration for this project was deeply personal. We as organizers both identify as survivors of sexual violence and women of color and this intersectional identity lays a large part of the foundation and importance of this project to us.  Our intention in creating The Art of Life After project is to create space for survivors and supportive communities to celebrate art and creativity that may have arisen from the complexity of a life including experiences of violence.

The Art of Life After started with one art show and through personal work and community support is developing into a larger multidimensional project. The next installment is The Art of Life After: Workshop Series, a weekend event that will focus on building strategies and capacities for self-care and community-care through creative and expressive healing workshops for survivors of intimate violence. The Workshop Series will culminate in a final show of voice and intentional witnessing, open to the public.

What We Need 

We are asking for $750 to support us in paying for an adviser with expertise in community organizing and clinical practice in social work and trauma. We will also use this money to provide small stipends for ourselves as organizers and pay for any extra expenses that the show may incur outside of our currently planned budget. 

The Impact

We are interested in opening up what it means to be survivors of intimate and sexual violence and co-creating community around these questions. We are interested in allowing survivorship to be a part of our lives in a way that we author for ourselves. The Art of Life After works to hold both the pain of experiencing intimate violences and the strength we have in ourselves and in the communities we can create. 

Twinned with the work of healing for survivors, is The Art of Life After's intention towards general community education around topics of sexual and intimate violence, decreasing stigmas associated with survivor identities, and building integration between our personal, inter-personal, and community lives.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are interested in the project but cannot support financially please support us by sharing this fundraising page and/or our website www.artoflifeafter.org. Also please stay tuned for our events coming this April 2016, which will all be free for the community to attend. We would be honored to have you be a part. Thanks for your support!

story:
#PhillyLovesPoetryFestival


Philly Loves Poetry is a five year project to create an annual Poetry Festival that celebrates the vibrant poetry community in Philadelphia and brings nationally known poets here to read and conduct workshops. Philadelphia, with a long history of literary and social diversity and a group of poetry organizations representing ethnic groups, educational institutions and various approaches to writing is a melting pot of ideas that lends itself to the development of a festival that celebrates the talent of Philadelphia based poets. Philly Loves Poetry 2016 consists of several elements: a multiple day program of readings and workshops; a collaboration with Brandywine Workshop to create a limited edition print honoring the life and work of the Philly Loves Poetry honoree Sonia Sanchez; and a newspaper that promotes the programs of the entire Philadelphia poetry community during April (Poetry month.)


How you can help and what you get for your money 

This, the first year of the Philly Loves Poetry Festival, does not have any foundation support and needs people who love poetry to demonstrate that a Philadelphia Poetry Festival is feasible and desirable.

- Please see contribution amounts and perks to the right.

       -Advertise in the Philly Loves Poetry Festival Newspaper

       -Purchase the print as part of the pre-publication offer

-Participate in the Poetry Ink Anthology and festival programs

-Volunteer: contact Larry Robin at larry@moonstoneartscenter.org or 215- 735- 9600

-Help us reach our goal by contributing. If you are not in the position to contribute financially, please share and encourage others to contribute. Thank you!

-Learn more about Moonstone Arts Center, our poetry events and all we have achieved at www.moonstoneartscenter.org


See Schedule of Events here

   


There are four major aspects of the festival each of which needs your help:

-Philly Loves Poetry Festival Newspaper – 15,000 copies of a 20 page newspaper will be produced, printed and distributed around Philadelphia. This will include not only information on the four day festival but will include information on dozens of Philadelphia poetry organizations and a listing of their April programs. Budgeted at $5000

-A limited edition print celebrating Sonia Sanchez and her life and work. A collaboration between Sonia Sanchez and Allan L. Edmunds. This print will incorporate photographs and poetry from Ms. Sanchez’s archives in a graphic format for which Mr. Edmunds is noted. Founded in 1972 by African American Master Printer Allan Edmunds, the Brandywine Print Workshop has for the past forty years produced lithographs from a plethora of local, national, and international artists to generate dialogues about the relationship between art and social engagement. Budgeted at $5000


-Four Days of Readings and Workshops. An array of national and Philadelphia based poets to celebrate Philadelphia’s vibrant community (see above). While much of the programs are free we will need to charge for some things.

-Moonstone Art Center’s infrastructure. After over 30 years of doing this work we know how to do it very inexpensively. While we believe that artists should get paid, we are not in the position to pay anyone. Still it costs money to keep the electricity on, to communicate with people, and to do all the things necessary to make a project work. Our overall budget for Philly Loves Poetry Festival is just under $40,000.

-20th Anniversary Anthology. 200 plus pages of poetry from poets who have read for Moonstone over the last several decades as well as those who are reading on April 17, 2016. Some famous, like Sonia Sanchez and Eleanor Wilner, some not. Mostly alive poets, but some like Dennis Brutus, not. This will be a terrific anthology.


“Nowhere else in Philly do we get such a wonderful mix of people, voices, and generations, and it is an experience in varieties of personalities as much as in poetry and poetics - everything from uplift to satire, from political protest to personal sorrow, love poems and tirades, transgression an decorum, the outrageous and the outraged, ranters and restrained formalists, street and academy, performance poets and shy ladies barely audible - pretty much the human spectrum. I loved listening...stayed a while, came back for more. Anyway, it was a great day...Only death is as great a leveler as Moonstone [Arts Center>.”  - Eleanor Wilner, author ofTourist in Hell; The Girl with Bees in Her Hair; Reversing the Spell: New and Selected Poems, and Otherwise.


Schedule of Events


Thursday, April 14, 2016– Women’s Day


6:00pm ­- Unsilenced: Four Women of Color - An interactive spoken word, music and dance performance honoring the legacies of four women artists and activists: Lorraine Hansberry, Sonia Sanchez, Nina Simone and Miriam Makeba, whose work has evidenced their commitment to social change.

8:00pm ­ Ten Women Poets Occupy the Workspace

Friday, April 15, 2016–Sonia Sanchez Day


   

5:30pm - Unveiling of the limited edition print, a collaboration between Sonia Sanchez and Allan L. Edmunds, which celebrates the life and work of Ms. Sanchez. This print will incorporate photographs and poetry from Ms. Sanchez’s archives in a graphic format for which Mr. Edmunds is noted. Individuals who pur chase this print before or at the event can have their photograph taken with Ms. Sanchez in front of the framed print.


7:00 pm ­ BaddDDD Sonia Sanchez: A new documentary (90minutes) – is a performance­ filled documentary about this 80­ year old artist for whom writing is both a personal and political act.

Saturday, April 16, 2016–Poetry as Personal History ­- A Day of Workshops

10:00am - TBA


11:30 - Gregory Corbin is Founder and Executive Director of the Philadelphia Youth Poetry Movement, an accomplished artist who has performed from South Carolina to South Africa. He has shared stages with India Arie, Mos Def, Talib Kweli, Saul Williams, Sonia Sanchez and many other powerful artists.


2:00 ­ Afaa M. Weaver - “Weaver offers up poems that accomplish the rare feat of describing both a foreign land… (and) he flawlessly incorporates his own personal history and personal struggles with his explorations of Asia and in doing so, makes his poetry all the richer instead of truncating or lessening either his autobiographical approach nor his geographical journey.


3:30pm ­- Amy Small­ McKinney founded a program using creative writing for healing. “Often, the only relief I’d get from fear and worry was to sit down and write... During the chemo, when I was really sick, I didn’t write as often, but it was always there for me. It was a ladder out of this well, this cave. I was drowning and it was my ladder out. So I’m grateful to poetry.”from an interview on April 22nd, 2015 in The Breast Cancer Journey.


5:00 pm - Sonia Sanchez - Poet. Mother. Professor. National and International lecturer on Black Culture and Literature, Women’s Liberation, Peace and Racial Justice. Sponsor of Women’s International League for Peace and Freedom. Board Member of MADRE. First Poet Laureate of Philadelphia, Sonia Sanchez is the author of over 16 books, most recently, Morning Haiku.

7:30pm – Saturday Night Reading –  TBA, Gregory Corbin, Sonia Sanchez, Amy Small­ McKinney, Afaa M. Weaver

Saturday April 16, 2016 – readings by theme: Place, Love & Relationships, Social Justice


Sunday April 17, 2016 – 20th Annual Poetry Ink: 100 Poets Reading is a free, open, festive, participatory community event, a day of poetry, refreshments and camaraderie. We embrace the concept that Poetry is for everyone and takes many forms; therefore we invite academic poets, famous poets, free form poets, street poets, unknown poets, spoken word poets, published poets, unpublished poets and everyone else, all reading for 3 minutes in alphabetical order.

Sunday April 17, 2016 – readings by theme: Using Music, Humor, Poetry as Performance.


-Learn more about Moonstone Arts Center, our poetry events and all we have achieved at www.moonstoneartscenter.org

#PhillyLovesPoetryFestival
Philly Loves Poetry is a five year project to create an annual Poetry Festival that celebrates the vibrant poetry community in Philadelphia and brings nationally known poets here to read and conduct workshops. Philadelphia, with a long history of literary and social diversity and a group of poetry organizations representing ethnic groups, educational institutions and various approaches to writing is a melting pot of ideas that lends itself to the development of a festival that celebrates the talent of Philadelphia based poets. Philly Loves Poetry 2016 consists of several elements: a multiple day program of readings and workshops; a collaboration with Brandywine Workshop to create a limited edition print honoring the life and work of the Philly Loves Poetry honoree Sonia Sanchez; and a newspaper that promotes the programs of the entire Philadelphia poetry community during April (Poetry month.)


How you can help and what you get for your money This, the first year of the Philly Loves Poetry Festival, does not have any foundation support and needs people who love poetry to demonstrate that a Philadelphia Poetry Festival is feasible and desirable.- Please see contribution amounts and perks to the right.       -Advertise in the Philly Loves Poetry Festival Newspaper       -Purchase the print as part of the pre-publication offer-Participate in the Poetry Ink Anthology and festival programs-Volunteer: contact Larry Robin at larry@moonstoneartscenter.org or 215- 735- 9600-Help us reach our goal by contributing. If you are not in the position to contribute financially, please share and encourage others to contribute. Thank you!-Learn more about Moonstone Arts Center, our poetry events and all we have achieved at www.moonstoneartscenter.org
See Schedule of Events here   There are four major aspects of the festival each of which needs your help:-Philly Loves Poetry Festival Newspaper – 15,000 copies of a 20 page newspaper will be produced, printed and distributed around Philadelphia. This will include not only information on the four day festival but will include information on dozens of Philadelphia poetry organizations and a listing of their April programs. Budgeted at $5000-A limited edition print celebrating Sonia Sanchez and her life and work. A collaboration between Sonia Sanchez and Allan L. Edmunds. This print will incorporate photographs and poetry from Ms. Sanchez’s archives in a graphic format for which Mr. Edmunds is noted. Founded in 1972 by African American Master Printer Allan Edmunds, the Brandywine Print Workshop has for the past forty years produced lithographs from a plethora of local, national, and international artists to generate dialogues about the relationship between art and social engagement. Budgeted at $5000-Four Days of Readings and Workshops. An array of national and Philadelphia based poets to celebrate Philadelphia’s vibrant community (see above). While much of the programs are free we will need to charge for some things.-Moonstone Art Center’s infrastructure. After over 30 years of doing this work we know how to do it very inexpensively. While we believe that artists should get paid, we are not in the position to pay anyone. Still it costs money to keep the electricity on, to communicate with people, and to do all the things necessary to make a project work. Our overall budget for Philly Loves Poetry Festival is just under $40,000.-20th Anniversary Anthology. 200 plus pages of poetry from poets who have read for Moonstone over the last several decades as well as those who are reading on April 17, 2016. Some famous, like Sonia Sanchez and Eleanor Wilner, some not. Mostly alive poets, but some like Dennis Brutus, not. This will be a terrific anthology.“Nowhere else in Philly do we get such a wonderful mix of people, voices, and generations, and it is an experience in varieties of personalities as much as in poetry and poetics - everything from uplift to satire, from political protest to personal sorrow, love poems and tirades, transgression an decorum, the outrageous and the outraged, ranters and restrained formalists, street and academy, performance poets and shy ladies barely audible - pretty much the human spectrum. I loved listening...stayed a while, came back for more. Anyway, it was a great day...Only death is as great a leveler as Moonstone [Arts Center>.”  - Eleanor Wilner, author ofTourist in Hell; The Girl with Bees in Her Hair; Reversing the Spell: New and Selected Poems, and Otherwise.
Schedule of EventsThursday, April 14, 2016– Women’s Day6:00pm ­- Unsilenced: Four Women of Color - An interactive spoken word, music and dance performance honoring the legacies of four women artists and activists: Lorraine Hansberry, Sonia Sanchez, Nina Simone and Miriam Makeba, whose work has evidenced their commitment to social change.
8:00pm ­ Ten Women Poets Occupy the Workspace
Friday, April 15, 2016–Sonia Sanchez Day




   
5:30pm - Unveiling of the limited edition print, a collaboration between Sonia Sanchez and Allan L. Edmunds, which celebrates the life and work of Ms. Sanchez. This print will incorporate photographs and poetry from Ms. Sanchez’s archives in a graphic format for which Mr. Edmunds is noted. Individuals who pur chase this print before or at the event can have their photograph taken with Ms. Sanchez in front of the framed print.




7:00 pm ­ BaddDDD Sonia Sanchez: A new documentary (90minutes) – is a performance­ filled documentary about this 80­ year old artist for whom writing is both a personal and political act.

Saturday, April 16, 2016–Poetry as Personal History ­- A Day of Workshops
10:00am - TBA



11:30 - Gregory Corbin is Founder and Executive Director of the Philadelphia Youth Poetry Movement, an accomplished artist who has performed from South Carolina to South Africa. He has shared stages with India Arie, Mos Def, Talib Kweli, Saul Williams, Sonia Sanchez and many other powerful artists.



2:00 ­ Afaa M. Weaver - “Weaver offers up poems that accomplish the rare feat of describing both a foreign land… (and) he flawlessly incorporates his own personal history and personal struggles with his explorations of Asia and in doing so, makes his poetry all the richer instead of truncating or lessening either his autobiographical approach nor his geographical journey.



3:30pm ­- Amy Small­ McKinney founded a program using creative writing for healing. “Often, the only relief I’d get from fear and worry was to sit down and write... During the chemo, when I was really sick, I didn’t write as often, but it was always there for me. It was a ladder out of this well, this cave. I was drowning and it was my ladder out. So I’m grateful to poetry.”from an interview on April 22nd, 2015 in The Breast Cancer Journey.







5:00 pm - Sonia Sanchez - Poet. Mother. Professor. National and International lecturer on Black Culture and Literature, Women’s Liberation, Peace and Racial Justice. Sponsor of Women’s International League for Peace and Freedom. Board Member of MADRE. First Poet Laureate of Philadelphia, Sonia Sanchez is the author of over 16 books, most recently, Morning Haiku.


7:30pm – Saturday Night Reading –  TBA, Gregory Corbin, Sonia Sanchez, Amy Small­ McKinney, Afaa M. Weaver
Saturday April 16, 2016 – readings by theme: Place, Love & Relationships, Social Justice




Sunday April 17, 2016 – 20th Annual Poetry Ink: 100 Poets Reading is a free, open, festive, participatory community event, a day of poetry, refreshments and camaraderie. We embrace the concept that Poetry is for everyone and takes many forms; therefore we invite academic poets, famous poets, free form poets, street poets, unknown poets, spoken word poets, published poets, unpublished poets and everyone else, all reading for 3 minutes in alphabetical order.

Sunday April 17, 2016 – readings by theme: Using Music, Humor, Poetry as Performance.

-Learn more about Moonstone Arts Center, our poetry events and all we have achieved at www.moonstoneartscenter.org

story:
Global Goddesses Coloring Book Fundraiser: The Cause

All funds raised for this hand-drawn coloring book will go towards a volunteer trip I'll be taking with Team4Tech. In March, I'll be spending two weeks working with a nonprofit in Siem Reap, Cambodia called Journeys Within Our Communities (JWOC) to implement technology and strengthen courses on English, digital literacy, and STEM programs for underserved youth and adults.  

I was interested in this project because I believe that technology has the power to create opportunity. It particularly resonated because both my parents were immigrants, and created successful lives in the US through careers in technology. I thought this project was a wonderful opportunity to use my background and expertise in technology to hopefully empower others as well.

Learn more about Team4Tech and their volunteer trips here.

Learn more about JWOC here.

Great Cause! But Why a Coloring Book?

I've been drawing and doodling as long as I can remember, and I've always been fascinated by mythology. As a young girl, I'd wile away hours in the library reading up on the shenanigans Greek goddesses and gods got into as if I were reading the tabloids. Once accepted into this project, I wanted something to be able to offer potential donors, and something that grew me as an artist. While brainstorming, I looked at the beautiful intricacy of Cambodian goddesses depicted in Angkor Wat online, started doodling... and the rest is history.  

And why goddesses? First, I'm a feminist and I love telling stories of strong women. Second, I am fascinated by how almost all cultures have powerful women in their mythology, and as I've done more and more research, I've been so inspired by their stories and their strength.

Here's a timelapse timelapse of me inking in Innana, the Sumerian goddess of love, fertility, and warfare.
 

And some photos documenting the process of Amaterasu, the Shinto goddess of the sun.

Where the Money Goes

The $4000 I hope to raise will go toward the following:

  • $2500 covers the cost of the project, including purchasing tablets and other peripherals (requested by JWOC) to be donated to organization, and also covers trip logistics
  • $900-1200 covers my flight (estimate)
  • $600-800 covers my printing costs (estimate)
  • Remaining funds will be used to cover Indiegogo's platform fee and any unexpected expenses associated with the project. After all expenses are covered, any remaining money will be donated to Team4Tech.

Note: Donations are NOT tax deductible. This is because I set up my fundraiser to cover my travel and book production expenses in addition to the donation to the nonprofit. If it’s important to you to get a tax write-off form, please consider donating to one of my teammates instead.

The Coloring Book Details

I've done a ton of research and spoken with many friends and family develop my final list  of 14 different goddesses to be featured.

I'm still working on the book, but I estimate it will be finished and delivered by the end of March.

Who I Am

I'm a proud first generation American, Bay Area native, and Cal bear. I get excited about my family, feminism, creative problem solving, acapella, drawing, puns, costume parties, snowboarding, and Burning Man. I work at Box, Inc as a Customer Success Manager. This trip is organized (and not funded) by Box and I will be taking this trip with seven of my coworkers.

Other Ways You Can Help

Know someone who digs the mindfulness aspect of coloring books, enjoys a good doodle, is a feminist, loves mythology, or wants to contribute to a good cause? I'd be super grateful if you can get the word out with friends and family! Share the link or use Indigogo's sharing tools.

Last -- THANK YOU THANK YOU THANK YOU for your interest in this project!!

story:
Digital graphic images by Scott Bridge

 

WHAT WE ARE CURATING 

 

We are building a 3 meter tall site specific sculpture of a leaf reduced to its veined skeletal state. The main structure of the sculpture will be made mostly organic materials while the base will be welded with steel rods to secure its position in the tough terrain of the desert. Among the organic matter we are sculpting with there will be wattle, mpepho (an indigenous smudging tool), organic chord and string (hemp) to weave skeleton leaf veins and leaf matter. All materials to be burnt will be made solely of environmentally friendly materials.

The gentle technique of weaving and knotting the geometric lace like veins of the leaf over the steel frame bring a significant feminine energy of creation to the project. This meditative process reflects the nurturing energy of earth as creator or mother, its patience reflected in the serene and perfectly balanced design of the natural world. It signifies its strength yet also its fragility which is seen in the way nature is exploited by humans in the contemporary world. This delicate method of sculpting and the sculpture as whole is a powerful metaphor for how we as the greater collective of human kind need to bring balance back into our relationship with the earth.

The sculpture will be placed in a position which will allow for the shadow of the leaf to create a sundial so that burners can tell the time when walking by. Another simple yet clever method of using the natural elements as a useful tool.

The space around the sculpture will host a series of holistic/conscious events as a general area for ‘holding space’. This will involve instrumental music sessions and sacred sound healing journeys, meditation, energy healing workshops etc.

 

 

WHY WE NEED YOUR HELP

 

The money raised for the project will go towards various elements such as materials for producing the sculpture as well as workshops to learn traditional weaving techniques which will be fused with our sculpting methods. The wattle used for the sculpture will be collected through deforestation as it is an invasive species in South Africa that has an high water consumption being extremely detrimental to the current dangerous drought experienced in the country. This will be performed ourselves at a specific site in Natures Valley over the course of a week thus needing funds to travel and sustain our team of women throughout. The funds will also cover camp costs in the desert as it is an off the grid harsh terrain where we need to prepare for and build an entire self sustainable living and working space to take care of and feed our crew in a community setting for 3 weeks.

 

HOW ELSE CAN YOU HELP?

 

You can also support us by following, sharing and connecting with our Facebook page; The Skeleton Leaf of Change 2018.  Where you can see our progress and what we are up to as we prepare for our desert build.

 

MORE ABOUT THE ARTISTS

Why the Skeleton Leaf of Change? A question that was asked of the group of young women whom form the collective that will build the structure. Answers consisted of;

Participating
Manifestation of a Dream
Passion
Collaboration 
Creativity
Learning
Higher purpose 
Nurturing 
Sisiterhood
Connection
Healing 
Safety
Empowerment  
Expantion
Power 
Eco build 
NO cellphones 

This collects the conscious mindset behind the ladies of the Skeleton Leaf of Change. An innovative group of artists that are collaborating together to create this holding space at Afrikaburn this year. 

  

Kiara Watermeyer is a young Zimbabwean artist residing in Cape Town. She is currently a freelancing artist, airbrushing decor and art installations. Working internationally for various decor crews and artists. She occasionally does live art performances (live painting & airbrushing) at festivals. Watermeyer graduated with a Bachelors of Fine Art at Rhodes University, Grahamstown in 2014. She has been involved with exhibitions focusing on experimental sound art such as "Language of Trees" a site specific installation at the Makana botanical gardens, Grahamstown, 2014.  

 

Watermeyer has been involved with past Afrikaburn installations, such as the Haupbahnhof 2016 & 2017.

Photo: Patrick Baumhoefer

 

Photo: Joffree Hyman Photography 

 

Watermeyer was part of 'The Shell, 2017’ crew of last year.

Photo: Duncan Rawlinson 


Photo: Paige Mila Rybko

 

Yasmin Ezzideen graduated with a BA in fine Arts with a major in sculpture at Michaelis in 2013. She is an artist that predominantly focuses on sculptural artworks that explore the human disconnect from the natural world. This can be considered environmental or conscious art. Often working with natural materials including found animal parts (taxidermy), insects, skeleton leaves and other unconventional sculpting materials. Yasmin often uses delicate modes of sewing and weaving as a sculpting technique throughout her installations. The process often involves gently and meticulously fixing parts of butterfly and moth wings or sewing skeleton leaves into an ethereal tapestry. The nurturing and patient qualities become a metaphor for how we can interact with nature to restore the imbalance which is reflected in the way the natural world is exploited.

Ezzideen curated a moth installation as part of Yggdrasil, Tree of Life, 2017 the largest build to feature at Afrikaburn, yet.

Photo: Duncan Rawlinson 

Photo: Duncan Rawlinson 

.

story:
The public’s response to Erie Open Figure Sessions has been overwhelmingly positive.

In order to offer more variation in each week’s pose, we are in need of props and other materials to keep the setup fresh for each session. This campaign has been set up with the goal of purchasing various materials to do so. Every dollar will go towards improving ErieOFS’ collection of props and materials. These items will include:

- A wide-ranging collection of fabrics varying in color

- Skull replicas and other anatomical props

- Geometric props such as blocks and colored cubes

- Costumes

- Replacement lightbulbs

- A larger model stand that can accommodate two models simultaneously

- Lumber and supplies to build eight drawing benches for artists who prefer to sit while working

story:
About Bridging the Gap: Preparing the Next Generation of Emerging Arts Leaders

In fulfillment of my Arts Administration M.A. program at Savannah College of Art and Design (SCAD), I am presenting a panel discussion on Sunday, May 8, 2016 focused on the arts leadership gap. This discussion will look at succession planning and how arts organizations can attract and retain emerging arts leaders to the field. 


With your help I can offer this event free to the public, pay for the venue, cover traveling costs, print materials, host a post-event networking reception with food and drinks, and give thank you gifts to panelists and volunteers. 

For more information about my project and what I hope to achieve through this campaign, check out my video. 

Please join me in this campaign with your generous contribution and by sharing this video with others. 

Want to attend?

**UPDATE: Event will now be held on SUNDAY, MAY 15TH** 
Interested in attending this event? RSVP here: http://presentingnextgenarts.eventbrite.com

story:
24:1

Two years ago, we entered the BFA program as 24 well-rested graphic design novices. After many, many late nights, caffeinated beverages, and morale-boosting karaoke sessions, our time at CSULB has come to a close. If you know us, you're familiar with just how much the program has consumed our lives over the last four semesters. You've heard and tolerated us rambling about projects, deadlines, and critiques incessantly. In one month, we'd like to share all of that hard work with you in person. This show is something we've been working towards since our first month as strangers. For two days, we are transforming Nobo gallery into our own curated graphic design experience - highlighting all of our individual and collaborative efforts as family: a celebration of our work, a goodbye to our studies, and a thank you to our supporters.

OUR GOAL

For this show to be as spectacular as we hope, there are inevitable expenses that come with the territory. We are entirely self-funded, and in preparation we've acquired income from two main sources: a fee we all contribute quarterly, and numerous fundraising events. But that doesn't mean we couldn't use a little extra boost from all of our friends, family, and supporters! All the money we've raised and the money we hope to raise from this campaign will go directly towards venue costs (which include rental and workers) as well as all the fees for set-up and printing. And as a little extra thank you, we will include an exclusive RESOLUTION-branded show item with your donation.

We'd greatly appreciate any contributions you can offer, but even if it's not possible, sharing our website and this donation page would help heaps!

THANK YOU from all 24 of us for the support. 

We hope to see all of your amazing faces at our show on May 26!

story:
Greetings From The Alchemist's Studio

My name is Jay, and I am a potter and writer.  I create one of a kind raku pottery.  Pottery is one of the most ancient art forms and crafts in the world.  With this ancient art form I pair retelling of myths and legends, mostly old and some new.  I would like to share my work with people and bring this to you and others to have in your home in the form of an 8.5 x 8.5 book.  You can see samples of my work and read some of the stories I create here.

Raku pottery is my great love in life.  I am passionate about sharing this unique process and my exploration of it with others in an accessible way for all.

By supporting this campaign you will allow me to print my first book and share my work with the world.

The Book

‘A Potter’s Dream: Myths & Legends’ pairs my pottery creations with myths and legends from around the world retold with my own quirky spin. It makes for a great coffee table book, bedtime reading, bathroom book or gift for the art lover on your shopping list.

‘A Potter’s Dream: Myths & Legends’ will be available to those who support our crowdfunding campaign. You can receive a digital copy of the book for $4! Printed copies are $25/each and include shipping within Canada and the United States. We also have a number of other perks that pair our pottery with this book, including one of a kind raku pieces, raku Christmas ornaments and the chance to work with us to create a vase and story to be included in the book as a special gift for someone you love.  All of our perks will be sent out in time for the holidays!

*Please note - Most perks with pottery are only currently available in Canada and the United States.  If you live elsewhere and are interested in one of these perks, email me here and I will provide you with the total cost of the perk with shipping and add it to the campaign.

You can read some customer reviews here, from those I have shipped pottery to in the past so you can support this campaign with confidence.

I am using this crowdfunding campaign to defray costs for an initial print run.  I am seeking at least half of my printing costs to move forward with this project and print the book, and that is the amount that I have set my goal for.  If I do not hit that goal you will not be charged for the project.  If I raise more money then the goal, it will go to the remaining half of the printing costs.  Any additional funds will be used to support my creative work in the studio and for future book projects.

I hope that this project will bring more appreciation and understanding for this ancient craft to the world and help share legends of old with the people of today in a way that entertains and engages people. 

This project is a natural next step from my recent art show 'The Myth of Family'.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to support this campaign, please consider sharing it with others who may be interested through social media.  It would mean so much to me.

Thank you for your consideration.  Any and all help is greatly appreciated.
story_txt:
Greetings From The Alchemist's Studio
My name is Jay, and I am a potter and writer.  I create one of a kind raku pottery.  Pottery is one of the most ancient art forms and crafts in the world.  With this ancient art form I pair retelling of myths and legends, mostly old and some new.  I would like to share my work with people and bring this to you and others to have in your home in the form of an 8.5 x 8.5 book.  You can see samples of my work and read some of the stories I create here.
Raku pottery is my great love in life.  I am passionate about sharing this unique process and my exploration of it with others in an accessible way for all.
By supporting this campaign you will allow me to print my first book and share my work with the world.
The Book
‘A Potter’s Dream: Myths & Legends’ pairs my pottery creations with myths and legends from around the world retold with my own quirky spin. It makes for a great coffee table book, bedtime reading, bathroom book or gift for the art lover on your shopping list.
‘A Potter’s Dream: Myths & Legends’ will be available to those who support our crowdfunding campaign. You can receive a digital copy of the book for $4! Printed copies are $25/each and include shipping within Canada and the United States. We also have a number of other perks that pair our pottery with this book, including one of a kind raku pieces, raku Christmas ornaments and the chance to work with us to create a vase and story to be included in the book as a special gift for someone you love.  All of our perks will be sent out in time for the holidays!
*Please note - Most perks with pottery are only currently available in Canada and the United States.  If you live elsewhere and are interested in one of these perks, email me here and I will provide you with the total cost of the perk with shipping and add it to the campaign.
You can read some customer reviews here, from those I have shipped pottery to in the past so you can support this campaign with confidence.
I am using this crowdfunding campaign to defray costs for an initial print run.  I am seeking at least half of my printing costs to move forward with this project and print the book, and that is the amount that I have set my goal for.  If I do not hit that goal you will not be charged for the project.  If I raise more money then the goal, it will go to the remaining half of the printing costs.  Any additional funds will be used to support my creative work in the studio and for future book projects.
I hope that this project will bring more appreciation and understanding for this ancient craft to the world and help share legends of old with the people of today in a way that entertains and engages people. 
This project is a natural next step from my recent art show 'The Myth of Family'.

Other Ways You Can Help

Thank you for your consideration.  Any and all help is greatly appreciated.

story:
Lets crush it!

Help us bring MerKaBa back to Playa, 20% larger with precision stainless steel construction and addressable LED's!

How you can help...

  • Currently we are in a rush to get the bulk of the fabrication done for Unscruz, Santa Cruz's regional event. In order to do this, we need to cover $1500 in expenses.
  • After, we need to raise an additional $2500 for electrical, finishing, upholstry, safety perimeter and logistics. 
  • Each of your contributions go directly towards these ends!

Make Burning Man dangerous again!

It's been a tremendous challenge to bring spinning metal to Playa, but with proper lighting, tolerances and trimming, we are going crush this project without hurting anybody!

Looking for volunteers!

  • We need volunteers for the assembly and tear down at Unscruz and possibly on Playa! please get in touch with me, lets be friends!

Thank you! David Date and To Be Continued... Collective

story:
INTRODUCTION

Hello friends! I’m excited to share that I have been accepted as an Artist in Residence at Green Olive Arts in Tetouan, Morocco!  This incredible, career altering opportunity will nurture my artistic practice to new levels. During my residency in Morocco, I will be exchanging thoughts, skills, and collaborating with other artists from around the world, local artisans, cultural groups, and the community in Tetouan, in the spirit of cultural exchange, greater cross-cultural understanding. My residency, beginning in late September, will focus on Moroccan fiber arts, I will learn about the deeply rooted history, traditional practice of weaving, embroidery, and textiles.

However, there are funds associated with maintaining a studio practice during my residency in Morocco, in order for me to take full advantage of this opportunity. I need your support! I invite you to Partner with me by pledging any amount you're willing. In exchange, I'm excited to take you on this journey with me and bring you back a piece of Morocco! 

**Click on each perk to see all included items and details**

ABOUT THE RESIDENCY, GREEN OLIVE ARTS

Green Olive Arts is an international art studio and urban art residency in Tetouan, Morocco, specializing in connecting creatives around the world with the culture, beauty and creatives of Morocco through professional studio facilities, custom and curated artist residencies, concierge services, instructional programming, and international collaborative events. Their mission is “to resource creative individuals of high caliber emerging and established artistic talent from around the world in seasons of inspiration, production, collaboration and cultural exchange here in Morocco.” Green Olive Arts is located in the 10-room home of a prominent Tetouani family, in the heart of this city – a few blocks from the King’s palace, numerous transportation arteries, museums, galleries and the gates of the medina itself.

ABOUT TETOUAN, MOROCCO

Situated in the North of Morocco, on the North-Western tip of Africa, Tetouan sits by the Mediterranean Sea in a beautiful valley at the intersection of two rugged mountain ranges. Tetouan’s ancient walled city is a UNESCO World Heritage Site with a rich history and culture hidden within. The city stands as a haven of old world artisanry, sumptuous spices, labyrinthine streets and dramatic landscapes. With its countless art festivals and associations, Tetouan has art “in its blood” at a grassroots level that is rarely seen in this part of the world.  Here you will find Morocco’s prestigious National Institute of Fine Art, National School of Architecture, the Royal Artisan School, and Morocco’s Museum of Modern Art.

FUNDING, WHAT I NEED TO GO

My goal is to raise $3,700 – This will help cover my studio fees, cost of materials, housing, food, and travel expenses for the duration of my time as an artist in residence at Green Olive Arts. Every bit helps, and even if I do not reach my goal, all funds raised will still go towards funding my residency at Green Olive Arts as much as possible.

  • $1300 - Roundtrip Airfare, Atlanta to Morocco
  • $750 - Residency Studio Fees
  • $780 - Housing in Morocco
  • $350 - Food/Groceries
  • $320 - Transportation
  • $200 - Art Materials

Additional funds after the initial goal is reached will go towards:

  • Shipping  & Insurance for Artwork to U.S. from Morocco
  • Taxes, Visa Fees, Inoculation fees
  • Incidentals + Emergency Fund
  • Miscellaneous Needs
  • Indiegogo Campaign Fees

In exchange for your support, I'm excited to take you on this journey with me and bring you back a piece of Morocco! Take a look at the exclusive perks I designed just for this campaign.

EXCLUSIVE PERKS –

  • Exclusive Updates - $5
  • Moroccan Postcard - $10
  • Moroccan Souvenir - $25
  • Limited Edition Art Book - $50
  • Limited Edition Art Print - $100
  • Original Artwork - $500

**Click on each perk to see all included items and details**

MY GRATITUDE

I'm often overcome with gratitude that I can practice art and share it with the world in hopes that my message of empowerment creates awareness and inspiration. I'm so proud to be part of such an amazing group of artists and humans, scattered near and far, brought together by art.  I'm incredibly excited to see where this new adventure will take me and my work, and it wouldn't be possible without your generosity!  I can not thank you all enough! Anything you are able to contribute, whether it be a donation or by sharing my campaign on your Instagram, Facebook, Twitter, with your community is greatly appreciated!

To learn more about me, feel free to visit my website at http://aleathalindsay.com

Please do check out the FAQ section here on Indiegogo to learn more.

Thank ya'll so much!

 

ABOUT ARTIST, ALEATHA LINDSAY

Aleatha Lindsay is an Atlanta based mixed media artist and independent curator. She holds a Bachelor of Arts from Russell Sage College (2011) and a Master of Arts from Savannah College of Art & Design (2013). She also studied Dance Movement Therapy in Corfu, Greece. After completing her studies, she went on to pursue posts in the mental health, arts community development, and special education arenas.

Deaf from the age of 2, she credits her early exposure to the arts with helping her overcome the challenges related to her disability. Her work has been purchased by collectors nationally and exhibited in Atlanta, New York, Spain, and Norway.

Lindsay is the Founder of The Ikouii Creative, an organization that supports artists with disabilities globally and assists organizations in adopting more inclusive attitudes.

Green Olive Arts  - Aleatha Lindsay - The Ikouii Creative

Facebook - Instagram - Blog

Thank ya'll so much!
 
ABOUT ARTIST, ALEATHA LINDSAY

story:
Short Summary

As an artist living with an anxiety disorder, drawing and coloring is an important therapy for me. I want to share this incredible tool with as many people as possible. These otherworld landscapes have been a joy for me to dream of and draw. I hope that they will heal you, spark your imagination, and inspire you to create your own stories of quiet magic. You can find more of my work at: https://coraleecreates.com/

 

What We Need & What You Get

I don't need to raise any specific amount for this project, as my production costs will be minimal. Half of the work is already complete—I have 6 coloring pages done so far.

For a one-time fee of $12, you'll get 12 coloring pages in the form of high-res PDFs that you can print and color as many times as you like. You'll receive 3 pages in the first month (May 2018) and one new page each month thereafter until February 2019, for a total of 12.

 

The Impact

All proceeds of this campaign will go to pay for funeral expenses for my sister Marsha, who passed away suddenly on April 13th. She suffered from epilepsy and we believe she had a fatal seizure during the night.  Marsha was 24 years old and pursuing a Bachelor's degree in Psychology. She is one of the most genuinely kind, open-minded and open-hearted people I have known. My family is devastated by this loss and now facing a heavy financial burden to pay for a funeral service. I hope to make this transition a little easier for all who are grieving. Thank you so much for your support.

If you would like to learn more about Marsha or give more, you can also visit Marsha's gofundme page: https://www.gofundme.com/marsha-lee-funeral

story:
IC 2018
1010101010101010101010101

Each of the 12 court cards have their own Zodiac artwork.


While the rest of the cards have art associated to their astrological meanings.

 

Custom pips for each suit representing the 4 elements

Fire

Earth

Water

Air

The Astrological Journey

  • A 54 card deck, each with unique digital artwork
  • Dimensions: 2.5" x 3.5" standard poker size.
  • 330gsm superior smooth black core card stock
  • Standard - 1st goal: High quality cards with UV coated gloss tuck box
  • Upgraded - 2nd goal High quality cards with glossy laminated 2 part rigid box for extra protection of cards as well as a higher quality look
  • Superior - 3rd goal: High quality cards with silver edging with glossy laminated 2 part rigid box for extra protection of cards as well as a higher quality look
  • See below for details on the goals

 

The Progress So Far

Hello! My name is Neil. I am the creator of the cards you've been looking at.

My girlfriend was the one who inspired me with her own Tarot cards to make this deck, however I added my own influence of astrology to it, something that I've always had a fascination with.

As I was creating the 12 court cards I discovered that each of the other cards have an astrological meaning to them. Something that was put into place by the three founding fathers of the Hermetic Order of the Golden Dawn, Dr William Wynn Wescott, Dr Robert Woodman and Samuel Mathers.

With this knowledge I went ahead and furthered my deck from a regular playing card deck into a deck that can be used for cartomancy.

Throughout the journey of creating these cards I've learnt so much. This knowledge is something I would like to share with everyone else who's interested by means of a book that goes along with the deck.

 

My Goals:

1st Goal:

  • My main goal is getting the deck into production and getting it into the hands of people who like it.
  • If the first goal is reached the deck will be produced with 330 gsm superior smooth black core card stock.
  • With a UV coated gloss tuck box.

2nd Goal:

  • Protection of these cards is important as well as making them look as amazing as possible.
  • So if the second goal is reached the card box will be upgraded to a glossy laminated 2 part rigid box.
  • The top quarter of the box will be the lid that comes off, making it easy to get the cards out.
  • The rigid box will add protection and preserve your cards for longer.

3rd Goal:

  • The ultimate goal for these cards is superior quality, taking them to a higher level of quality.
  • If the third and final goal is met the cards will be upgraded to a silver finish around the edges as well as the 2 part rigid box.


An overview of the goal and perks :)

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you like my idea and can't spare a dollar, please spread the word. That is value in itself! I will be most appreciative

Follow The Astrological Journey on Instagram 

       Share The Astrological Journey on Facebook

story:
The Company 

Inga Odette and Siri Gussiaas, two Norwegian actors based in New York City, founded Milk Melk Theater Company in March 2016. Our goal with the company is to create our own work by writing and producing performance pieces where we mix different artistic genres to create art that inspires and affects the audience.

Our first original play is They Never Stop Talking, a short play about two young women who have escaped their reality and find themselves in an alternative universe.

What We Need

In order to create the play's alternative universe we need build a world with lights, sound and videos. All the donations will go directly into light, set, costume and sound design, as well as rental of rehearsal space and marketing materials

The Impact

They Never Stop Talking will be a part of the NYWinterfest Festival in the end of February. This is the very first time our new play will presented on a stage. For Milk Melk Theater Company this will be a stepping stone to further development of the play. Your donation will help us create a show of quality that will set the standard for future productions by Milk Melk Theater Company.

If you are unable to donate at this time, we would greatly appreciate if you would pass along our campaign to your friends or other people you may know who may be interested in helping Milk Melk Theater Company getting established as a theater company in New York City.

 

Thank you!

Milk Melk Theater Company

https://www.facebook.com/milkmelkcompany

 

 

They Never Stop Talking will be presented

February 23rd at 6:15 pm

February 24th at 6:15 pm

February 26th at 8:30 pm

at The Hudson Guild Theatre

441 W 26th st

story:
August Update: Thanks to the generosity of many backers, my campaign surpassed it's initial goal. You can still contribute and purchase art through this site to support my work and residency. Thank you! kmw.

~~~~~~~~~~

Welcome to my campaign. I know you’re busy so thanks for taking the time to visit. Here’s my story…

I was recently awarded a one-month residency at The Rensing Center in Western South Carolina for the month of September 2015. While there I will have the chance to focus almost exclusively on my work, something all artists wish for, but few get to experience.

First, I’ll continue working on mixed media intuitive paintings and prints using objects and inspiration I find at the Center. Organic and synthetic objects are glued and sewn to the painted canvas to explore the byproducts and ephemera of physical existence and the human-nature connection. You can see and read more about my projects on my website, and by subscribing to “studio news”.

I'm also planning to begin working on a new project for an exhibit scheduled for May 2016! This exhibit will focus on my experiences and observations of the social media landscape (Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram) as a digital immigrant (someone who didn’t grow up with digital technology). 

Monarch, 2015, mixed media and oil on canvas. ©kristen m. watson art studio, LLC.

How you can help

All you have to do is choose which "perk" you want and then make your purchase. This campaign is an all-or-nothing funding platform, and if we do not make our financial goal no one will be charged and rewards will not be sent. We don't want this to happen! So please contribute what you can; any amount is greatly appreciated. Sharing this page is a great way to help too! 

Anticipated minimum costs:

Flight & baggage:                 

$650

Shipping fees: 

$400

Room & board:  

$1300

On-site supplies:  

$400

Gasoline:  

$210*

SUB TOTAL:    

$2,960

Indiegogo fees:  

$240

TOTAL MINIMUM COST: $3200.00

*My super mom is lending me her car for the month. I’m picking it up in Virginia.

Please note that the goal amount ($3,200) is less than the total costs associated with this residency.

And in Return...

In exchange for your support you’ll receive rewards such as post cards, high quality art prints, and original art. 

Please note that shipping is FREE for most of the perks (despite the "+ shipping" label that appears)...a system glitch.  Please check the perk description.

Contributors will also receive blog updates documenting my experiences during the residency, along with pictures of works in progress. 

There’s sure to be something for almost every preference and budget.  Remember that these can make great gifts too. As the campaign moves forward, I'll be adding more art, so if there's something you want and you don't see it here let me know by leaving a comment on this page.  

To view full size images visit the {stratum} series.



Risks & Challenges

The greatest challenge I foresee is transporting my equipment and supplies to and from the residency. I am making plans as we speak to minimize this risk by making arrangements to have supplies shipped direct from art supply companies to the Rensing Center and to purchase some supplies after I arrive. I am also planning to work on a scale that can be (relatively) easily shipped back to Vermont. 

As most of you know, my work and studio practice hinge on transparency, so I’ll be sharing all the adventures and misadventures along the way via my new blog and through direct updates.  I’ve no doubt that they’ll all lead to amazing growth in my work.  

To see the full size images visit Intuitive paintings.


To see full size images visit "Antipode" series.


Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word! Whether you give financially or not, you can help further by sharing the link to this campaign with your friends on Facebook, Instagram, via email or telling someone by text or word of mouth. You can make a huge contribution to the success of the campaign by making some noise and getting the word out however you like to do it. 

Click here for full size image of "Autumn Stillife" and here for full size image of "Blush Case"

A little about me, and why your support is vital

I wasn't always an artist, or at least I didn't call myself an artist until a few years ago, and I'm still working on feeling the conviction of the word when I say it. But step by step, day by day, it's beginning to sink in that I've been blessed with this amazing life and the inspiration to translate a little bit of myself into art works that I create and share with you.  

Following a three-year bout with a life-threatening illness, I was compelled to reexamine my career choice. Changes were in order. I wanted to do something meaningful and healing every day. Even though I have always loved making art, I feared change and the unknown. But I knew that if I recovered I had to leave a medically-oriented career to begin again as an artist.  

It wasn't an easy transition, but with the steady support of friends and family, I'm now fully engaged in my new life and work. I’ve built a home studio where I work almost every day. My art is shown regularly in local and regional exhibits and held in private collections. I've been selected as an artist in residence at two local programs including the Vermont Studio Center, and I get to nurture other artists through my teaching practice.  I am so humbled and thrilled to have this residency opportunity to focus on developing my practice. 

It’s not easy to ask others for money, even if you’re giving them something in return. Please know how much I appreciate your contribution/purchase. It validates my efforts and my work. Thank you. 

   



Magnolia, acrylic & oil pastel on canvas, 18 x 24"


Violet Landscape, acrylic, watercolor, textiles, pearl strands on canvas, 30x40"
story_txt:
August Update: Thanks to the generosity of many backers, my campaign surpassed it's initial goal. You can still contribute and purchase art through this site to support my work and residency. Thank you! kmw.~~~~~~~~~~Welcome to my campaign. I know you’re busy so
thanks for taking the time to visit. Here’s my story…

I
was recently awarded a one-month residency at The Rensing
Center in Western South Carolina for the month of September
2015. While
there I will have the chance to focus almost exclusively on my work, something
all artists wish for, but few get to experience.
First, I’ll
continue working on mixed media intuitive paintings and prints using objects and
inspiration I find at the Center. Organic and synthetic objects are glued and
sewn to the painted canvas to explore the byproducts and ephemera of physical
existence and the human-nature connection. You can see and read more about
my projects on my website, and by
subscribing to “studio news”.
I'm also planning to begin working on a new project for an
exhibit scheduled for May 2016! This exhibit will focus on my experiences and
observations of the social media landscape (Facebook, Twitter, and
Instagram) as a digital immigrant (someone who didn’t grow up with digital
technology). 
Monarch, 2015, mixed media and oil on canvas. ©kristen m. watson art studio, LLC.How you
can help
All you have to do is choose which "perk" you want and then
make your purchase. This campaign is an all-or-nothing
funding platform, and if we do not make our financial goal no one will be
charged and rewards will not be sent. We don't want this to happen! So please
contribute what you can; any amount is greatly appreciated. Sharing this page
is a great way to help too! 
Anticipated minimum costs:






Flight & baggage:                 


$650




Shipping fees: 


$400




Room & board:  


$1300




On-site supplies:  


$400




Gasoline:  


$210*




SUB TOTAL:
     


$2,960




Indiegogo fees:  


$240




TOTAL MINIMUM COST: $3200.00
*My super mom is lending me her car for the month.
I’m picking it up in Virginia.

story:
The Story

We are Elia Mrak (USA) and Nancy López Luna (MEX).

We are performers who come from different backgrounds, cultures, and dance styles.  Soon after meeting in 2014 we recognized that we share a unique talent to be successful dancers in the dance-specific art world, while also building a bridge from dance to everyday people in the form of workshops and movement research. Our mission is to combine our artistic and community work, using the body as a medium for empowerment and change; it is how we participate in the world.  

We have worked together in Mexico, USA and Europe, and are currently internationally touring our first evening-length duet, Whimsical.  Individually, we have performed with international choreographer/master David Zambrano, been a finalist on the national television program "Opera Prima" (imagine "So You Think You Can Dance?" of Mexico), won "Best Female Dancer" in Mexico in 2014, taught at Mark Morris Dance Center and Cornish College of the Arts, one of 50 recipients of the Watson Fellowship nationwide, and multiple year-long fellowships from the Mexican government, FONCA. In 2015, we were the only recipients from the Western Hemisphere for the ACASA Residency in Sicily, Italy to teach and direct a new performance, Walkabout.

Now, we are looking for support to produce our next dance/theater performance in 2016 – Absence.

It is a dance/theater piece directed by renowned Mexican theater director, Adrián Vásquez. It investigates the necessity of love through the presence and disappearance of the other, la ausencia.

This idea began in late 2014 when we connected with Adrián Vásquez in Mexico City, after seeing his powerfully raw solo performance, El Hijo de Mi Padre - which he also wrote and directed - based on his childhood in the streets of Tijuana.  

We all met again in Mexico City in 2015, surrounded by a surge in violence, and the murder of people known to Nancy and Adrián.  We were affected by those events and met at his house to discuss how those emotions and thoughts could be transformed into a performance.

We wanted to fuse our expressive physicality and experience in dance with his world of theatrical storytelling - to tell a story that makes you laugh, cry, and reflect.

This project has 3 parts:

+ Creation process in Mexico City (February - April 2016)

+ Premier in Mexico City (April 2016)

+ Premier in Seattle (May 2016)

To produce this project, we need 100+ people, and 3 types of producers: “Producer”, “Collaborator” and “Supporter.”  This is our mechanism of producing this project through community.

The Funding

The funding structure offers people an opportunity to opt-in and support art production directly. Many things today are more direct, and art production can leverage the same wave.  By producing this project, we can bypass institutional inefficiency; every dollar will go directly towards the final artistic production.

And in turn, your support will be supported. We already have a commitment from Producers in both countries - Steven Ripley (USA) and Ethnofit (Mexico) to help launch the project. 

The Economics

We need $13,120.  This number is precise, because it will be necessary to produce this project successfully in both Mexico and the USA. Your support will produce:

+ director fee

+ dancer / co-creator fee

+ premiers in Mexico City and Seattle

+ theater rental

+ rehearsal studios

+ travel from Mexico to USA

+ production (costumes, assistant, etc.)

+ marketing and publicity

+ video documentation


To cover these expenses, we need 3 types of producers:

1. Producer ($369 per "Producer")

A team of 10 “Producers” = The Director Fee + Video + Premier (5.5%)

2. Collaborator ($148 per "Collaborator")

A team of 25 “Collaborators” = Co-Creator Fee + Marketing + Premier (5.5%)

3. Supporter ($21 per “Supporter”)

A team of 65+ “Supporters” = Travel + Costumes

The People

We are Nancy López Luna from Xalapa, Ver. México and Elia Mrak from Seattle, WA United States. 

Nancy is passionate about the body’s capacity as a medium to transform energy. She began her professional ballet training as a young girl, and in 2008 was part of the company "le Jeune Ballet du Quebec" in Montreal, under Didier Chirpaz.  She later graduated from the University of Veracruz, in contemporary dance and won a scholarship "Instituto Superior" to dance in Havana.  She has danced with many renowned choreographers in Mexico and she won the scholarship "Creadores Escénicos 2013-14 del FONCA, México" to produce her independent artistic work.  In addition to performing and creating, she teaches workshops, specifically one titled, "Re-Conexiones" influenced by the work she has done with renowned psychoanalyst Sven Doehner.

In 2014, she won the "Premio Nacional" - best female dancer in Mexico.

Elia graduated with a degree in Mathematical Economics from Pomona College in 2007, and was awarded the Watson Fellowship to pursue his path through the body.  He went on to perform, teach, and direct throughout the last decade of working in Europe, Central and South America, and the USA. He includes in his list of masters: David Zambrano (BELGIUM), Park Young-Cool (KOREA) and Break-dancer FeverOne (USA/Rocksteady).  Learning from greats, his practice now fuses Martial Arts, Breakdancing, Flying Low, and dramaturgy of the theater.  Straddling the world of dance and movement, he is a personal trainer and professional development director, leading independent initiatives that build community through fun and movement, and healthy lifestyle.

Presently, we dedicate our training to movement exploration, improvisation, somatic practices, Qigong (breathing and meditation), and traditional dance forms.  We dance, walk, run, climb, and love to explore terrain in different forms. 

In 2014 we established Los Porcupines as an artistic collaboration between Mexico and the USA.  Our larger overall mission includes teaching, directing, and building bonds with different cultures and people through art.  Both of our unique cultures are important to us, and working with the body to dissolve borders and connect with people is essential.  Our workshops focus on breath, movement, and musicality.  They have included: “Workshop for Womanhood”; “Breakdancing for non-Breakdancers”; “Terrain”; “In-between Hands and Feet”; “Horizontal/Vertical”; and “Re-Connections”. 

(To see samples of our work, please check out our videos and photos in the "Gallery" section of this page above.)

Past Success

In 2011, Elia used “Kickstarter” (another crowd-sourcing online platform) to organize and direct a USA tour of 11 international dancers through community support.  And as a direct echo of that project, many of us still work together today, teaching, performing, investigating, and innovating in the world of art, education, and physical health for everyday people.

The Challenges

Accomplishing this project is not simple.  But being able to negotiate and overcome challenges is part of being a professional dancer.  We are disciplined and organized; we are hardworking artists.  Independently and together, we have produced dozens of previous works, and are equipped to overcome the pitfalls that exist during an intensive production process.  We will keep the process transparent, updating our Facebook page and email list as we document the process.

The Other Ways You Can Opt-in

In building this community of support, there are many ways to participate.  We understand that some people cannot contribute money.  But we would still love for you to be part of our work.  Here's how:

+ Vote with your feet and come to the show, in Mexico City or Seattle.

+ Forward our page onto 5 friends who could help make our project a reality.

+ Watch our videos, and reach out to us with any message you are inspired to share.

Thank you and Muchas Gracias.  To all.

story:
Local Flowers

This venture is a collaboration between three women whose life work revolves around growing and designing with fresh flowers, and more importantly, North Carolina grown flowers.  Across the country, people are learning about and believing in the benefits of locally grown flowers:

  • Reduced carbon footprint with less travel and packaging. Almost 80% of the flowers sold in the US are imported from other countries.
  • Less pesticides and chemicals. Imported flowers need to be sprayed to survive the weeks-long journey across borders and to retailers, while small farms usually grow with sustainable land practices and other organic methods.
  • A stronger local economy. Many flower farms, especially in the Piedmont, are small family farms providing for their local communities.
Plus local flowers smell better, last longer, and are more beautiful!

Art in Bloom

North Carolina Museum of Art’s annual festival of art and flowers is happening this year April 7–10, 2016. Floral designers from across North Carolina and beyond interpret masterworks from the permanent collection in breathtaking flower displays. 

We are building a large-scale outdoor installation for the festival—the only installation that will be created completely out of locally grown flowers. Our goal is to spread awareness about the impact of locally grown flowers by creating a beautiful, memorable image capturing the beauty of North Carolina.

The Impact

Your contribution will help us cover the costs of the flowers and materials used in the installation, plus our time and labor. We are full time business owners and farmers taking significant time away from our businesses to create something special. In addition, an immense amount of flowers, foliage, and other materials will be harvested and used in creating this project rather than being sold at market. $750 will cover the basic amount of materials; everything raised over that amount will help us cover extra materials used to replenish the installation through the week, harvesting time, and travel expenses.

Risks & Challenges

The challenge of dreaming up and building a living piece of art is matched only by the hurdle of keeping organic flowers alive and fresh for the duration of the festival, 5 days or more. We won't be using sprays or anything else to artificially preserve our flowers, which will need to stand up to heat, sun, wind and rain. We will be traveling to Raleigh and freshening the installation every day, replenishing with new flowers and material if necessary.


The Designers

Alice White - Bluebird Meadows Farms
Maggie Smith - Pine State Flowers
Stephanie Hall - Sassafras Fork Farm

story:
Help us Create a Magnificent Stage for a Fantabulous Burlesque/Cabaret & Variety Show at Burning Man Arts Festival 2013.

Our Project

Each year at Burning Man, The "G-Spot" theme camp builds its day bar: a popular oasis where weary wanderers can enjoy cool shade, tasty libations, DJ's and some of the best conversation on the playa.

This year we are taking our hospitality to a new level with a magnificent performing arts stage called "The Imaginarium of Dr. Ernst Grafenberg."

Designed by producer and performer Dane Ballard (The Grimaldis, New Paris Burlesque), this whimsical stage will be a beautiful piece of art in its own right, but more importantly the Imaginarium will serve to host a myriad of burlesque, cabaret, and circus performers from all over the country.

Ernst Gräfenberg  was a German-born physician and scientist. He is known for developing the intrauterine device, and for his studies of the role of the woman's urethra in orgasm. The G-Spot is named after him.

What We Need

We are raising funds not only for the raw materials to build the stage (lumber, paint, hardware, etc.) and resources to get said stage to Black Rock City (trailers and fuel), but also for some of the props, costumes and technical gear we need to put on a truly amazing show.

Other Ways You Can Help

While even a very small donation can really help our cause, we know some people are just not in a place to make any kind of contribution -- but you can still help by spreading the word on our fundraiser. The more people that know about it... the more likely we are to reach our goals.

Also, if you are a talented perfomer and would like to share your skills on our stage... Drop us a line.

Thanks for your support! See you on the Playa!

What We Need
We are raising funds not only for the raw materials to build the stage (lumber, paint, hardware, etc.) and resources to get said stage to Black Rock City (trailers and fuel), but also for some of the props, costumes and technical gear we need to put on a truly amazing show.
Other Ways You Can Help
While even a very small donation can really help our cause, we know some people are just not in a place to make any kind of contribution -- but you can still help by spreading the word on our fundraiser. The more people that know about it... the more likely we are to reach our goals.
Also, if you are a talented perfomer and would like to share your skills on our stage... Drop us a line.
Thanks for your support! See you on the Playa!

story:
Over the past few years photography has become a passion of mine.  During the summer, I decided to take my passion and make something of it.  Recently my photography was accepted in a local art show, Raw:Natural Born Artists in Raleigh.  I hope that this art show will help be the platform I need to jump start my career into photography.

My goal is to raise $500.  Raw asks its artists to sell 20 $10 tickets. However many tickets go unsold, the artist must pay the difference.  Since the show is on a Wednesday night, and all of my family and many of my friends live far away, I doubt many people will be able to make it even if they wanted to.  Therefore, $200 will cover my entry fee into the show.  

The remaining $300 will cover the supplies I need for displaying and selling my photographs.  This includes printing (paper, ink, and printing lab costs), matting and framing prints, business cards, storage, etc.

Feel free to take a look at my work: http://kadwellenz.smugmug.com/ 

If you want to help support my photography, I want to give you something in return for your help.

If you give $10, I will send you a 5x7 glossy print of any photograph in my collection.

If you give $25, I will send you an 8x10 and a 5x7 glossy print of your choice.

If you are able to give $50 or more, I will send you either a fully matted ready to frame 8x10 glossy print or two 8x10 prints of your choice.

Thank you in advance for your support.
