story:
Hi, I’m Kate. 

I’m an artist living in Norfolk, Virginia.

I’ve been enamored with the beauty around me since I was a little girl growing up in Manistee, Michigan and have spent a lot of my life since then working to translate that beauty into art.

In college, I studied in both the Two-Dimensional and Three-Dimensional programs at the Visual Arts Center in Portsmouth, VA  which means I was able to practice not just drawing and painting but glass-blowing, pottery, and sculpture. I loved every minute of it. 

I’ve been lucky enough to work out of my home studio and offer my art at festivals, online, and at shows for the past 8 years.

I’ve become known for my watercolor on canvas pieces,  mostly abstracted landscapes, florals, and deconstructions, all working to capture and convey that same beauty-feeling.

Lately though, I’ve been feeling the pull to do something more as an artist.  

I’m still enamored with the beauty around us, but I’ve become more and more enchanted by the beauty that’s inside of us too. 

I’ve been leading a lot of workshops and classes for adults this past year, and what I keep seeing is that many of us are so caught-up in our daily stress that we’ve let that child-like, free, beautiful part in us get drowned out by everything else. 

Helping people reconnect with and explore that part of themselves is beautiful on its own, I’ve loved doing it and want to do it more.

And I feel like my next step as an artist is to really lean into that, to help people bridge that gap between the beauty inside them and the beauty in the outside world, because when that happens, when people give themselves permission to see it more often, and to feel it more deeply - that beauty gets multiplied exponentially. 

But I don’t have a space to do that consistently, so I just kept painting in my back room and dreaming

Then I got a call about a space…

It’s not huge, but it’s big enough; and it’s in the perfect location, right on the corner of Colley and 44th. 

And it will allow me  to start doing the types of things I’ve been dreaming of…

Things like:

Open Studio Nights - A night to hang art all over and invite the community to come soak it in. 

Workshops - Where we can really focus on being loose and tapping into that part of ourselves that we don’t get to see very much. 

Collaborations- The chance to work with other artists who want to bring more beauty to the world too. 

Plus we’ll be able to do lots of other fun stuff like Kids Classes, Healing Art Nights, Girls Night Out, Dinners With The Artist…

A place to bring the healing power of community, creativity, and art to this part of Norfolk in a real way that’s accessible for everyone. 

It will also be a space that allows me to paint bigger. Painting big is always something I'm itching to do.

My head is spinning with ideas, I’m so excited to share more with you once we get it up and running. 

 

What I Need & What You Get

Here’s the thing, I did not go out looking for this space, it sprung up on me, and I can’t make it happen on my own. 

I need help getting these beauty-multipliers out into the world. 

Will you consider joining me in that?

The goal for this campaign is $8,000. 

Almost all of that will go directly to cover the rent, but some of it will go toward things I’ll need for the space like a sign, a couple of tables for workshops, and some chairs, insurance, signage and things like that. 

For helping me bring this dream to reality, you’ll be able to choose from some really fun perks at lots of different levels. 

I have everything from packs of notecards with my art on them, to studio dinners, tours of the Chrysler, painting lessons, in-home art consultations and lots of others at every level. 

I even made an Indiegogo-only painting and prints you can only get here during the campaign. 

If I don’t get the full amount, that’s ok, all the funds will still go towards making this space a reality. 

 

Challenges

To be honest with you, I’m excited but I’m nervous too!

The cliche of the “starving artist” exists for a reason. I’ve been very lucky to be able to have been a full-time artist for the past 8 years, but this is a stretch for me. 

Signing a lease with a rent bill every month is a big commitment. 

But I’m passionate about bringing this kind of art and these kinds of connections to Norfolk, and this space is so perfect for all of it, I feel like I have to go for it. 

I’m all-in and I’m going to do everything I can to make it work. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Any help you are able to offer really does mean a lot to me. 

If you can pitch in and pick out some perks, great! If you can’t pitch-in right now, that’s completely fine too! 

There are other ways to help out if money is tight right now. 

Please help me spread the word on social media, send the link to your auntie, your BFF, and your neighbors. Tell your HR department I do awesome corporate workshops… Help me get the word out! 

Indiegogo has some great built-in share tools, look for the share button and post it on your social media, it really is helpful, the more people that see it the better, and sometimes it takes a few nudges for people to remember that they wanted to do it :)

(I am going to check through the shares a couple times during the campaign and pick a couple to give a gift so get in on that too!)

Thanks so much for checking out my campaign and for reading all of this. 

I really do appreciate you, and feel so lucky to have all the support I do. 

- XO, Kate

story:
Christine Simard (conceptrice du projet et danse)

Christine travaille dans le domaine des sciences naturelles depuis 28 ans, d'abord comme naturaliste interprète et assistante de recherche en écologie forestière. Parallèlement elle pratique la danse et expérimente diverses approches dans le mouvement. Le Buto, le contact improvisation, le flamenco et le tango argentin contribuent à la construction du langage qu’elle développe au gré de son inspiration. Christine travaille également au sein du Papillon blanc, danse; un organisme qui intervient auprès des personnes en perte d'autonomie.

Passionnée de nature, cette dernière nourrit une grande partie de la production photographique qu’elle expose dans des organismes ou galeries de la région de Québec.​

 

Julia-Maude Cloutier (danse)

Julia-Maude est interprète et chorégraphe en danse contemporaine. Elle pratique en parallèle des arts physiques tels la capoeira et l'art du déplacement (parkour). Sa recherche est ancrée dans le mouvement, ce que le corps athlète a comme possibilité créative. Au centre de ses préoccupations : l'être humain et les relations entre individus. Pour ce faire, elle préconise le travail in situ et multidisciplinaire.

 

Maryse Damecour (danse, participation bénévole)

Après des études en sociologie (université), Maryse complète le programme de l’École de danse de Québec. Depuis 2009, elle œuvre en danse, performance, musique et théâtre auprès d’artistes tels que Daniel Bélanger, Hanna Ab Del Nour, Laurence Brunelle-Côté et Kira Kirsch. Maryse poursuit la sincérité dans la danse. Elle cherche un geste complet, qui est sous tendu par une émotion, un état corporel, un regard, une attention, une intention, un désir. Elle appelle une danse motivée par les mouvements intérieurs et profonds tout en conscientisant la forme matériel du corps. Sa motivation artistique est la communication et la transmission. Alliant la danse, la performance, les arts visuels, la musique et la parole, Maryse adresse des thématiques sociales et humaines et vise à participer à la réflexion collective autant sociétale qu’artistique.

 

Stéphanie Gaudreau (danse)

Photo : Charles Bélisle - @belisle.pro

Thérapeute par le mouvement, danseuse, pédagogue et femme de la terre, depuis 1996 elle dédie sa vie professionnelle à l’Être humain.

Engagé activement depuis 1992 dans la communauté de Contact Improvisation, fondatrice de l’ACI à Montréal et de « Danse Orée des bois » situé dans la pleine nature de l’Estrie.

 

Marie-Noëlle Goy (danse)

Après des études professionnelles en danse contemporaine et classique en France, Marie-Noëlle Goy soucieuse d'approfondir sa démarche artistique s’est également formée à l’animation culturelle, au théâtre, à la création et l’animation de projets artistiques et culturels. En 1994, elle va s'investir dans la fondation du centre culturel et artistique le Café des Arts de Québec.

Danseuse, comédienne et metteure en scène, tour à tour, c'est la passion pour l'être humain vulnérable et fragilisé par la maladie qui va la pousser à plonger dans un projet novateur de danse à l’hôpital en cofondant Le Papillon blanc, danse (OBNL) en 2013.

Sa démarche est soutenue par un élan intérieur de beauté, de vérité et de vitalité qui articule sa danse et sa présence vers l'harmonie et le bien-être. Elle crée ainsi des visites dansées et des médiations culturelles dans les CHSLD, CRDI, Hôpitaux et centres de cancérologie du Québec.

 

​Andrée Levesque-Sioui (chant)

Andrée est Wendat de la communauté de Wendake près de Québec, sa ville natale. Auteure mélodiste interprète, elle affectionne particulièrement les possibilités qu’offrent l’improvisation et les jeux rythmiques de sa tradition orale. La voix devient, cet instrument de quête d’oralité enfouie, l’éveil d’une mémoire par le chant, la langue et les tambours. Au-delà du style musical, c’est l’authenticité de la démarche humaine au cœur de l’expérience vocale qui l’interpelle. Chaque style lui permet d’explorer certains aspects de sa personnalité et l’ouvre à de nouveaux espaces.

En suivant diverses formations, elle a exploré le chant classique et gospel, le yoga du son, le chant choral, Estill voice training et le théâtre. Innucadie 2017, Gala prix du gouverneur général 2017, Ensemble nous sommes Québec, Kiugwe, Jeux para-panaméricains 2015, WendaKébec, Bruits du monde, Kwahiatonhk, murmures et torrents de la grande tortue, Les 4 directions, Libérons les voix etc. Elle est l’interprète principale de trois albums: Yahndawa’ (2011), (meilleure réalisation d’album aux Native American Music Awards 2013 et meilleure musique du monde aux Eworld Music Award 2012); Fais dodo mon trésor (2012) et Ozalik (2013). Elle a chanté sur la chaîne APTN pour l’émission TAM. Engagée dans sa communauté, elle y enseigne la langue wendat auprès des jeunes et des adultes depuis 2010.  

 

Jean Désy (poésie)

Jean est né au Saguenay. Il enseigne à l’Université Laval à Québec, en médecine et en littérature. Il pratique toujours la médecine en tant que dépanneur dans le pays cri de la Baie-James et au Nunavik. Parmi ses dernières parutions, un recueil de récits d’inspiration médicale intitulé L’accoucheur en cuissardes, publié aux éditons XYZ en avril 2015; un recueil de poésie en collaboration avec Normand Génois et intitulé Bras-du-Nord, en septembre 2015, aux éditions Mémoire d’encrier; un court essai sur le métissage et la métisserie, paru en septembre 2016 chez Mémoire d’encrier, intitulé Amériquoisie; un essai portant sur la spiritualité, paru en mars 2017 chez XYZ éditeur, en collaboration avec Isabelle Duval

 

André Beaudoin (vidéo drone)

André est passionné de nature, de musique et de photographie depuis toujours. En particulier, il a une solide formation en piano classique acquise à l'École Vincent d'Indy de Montréal et il a décroché quelques prix dans des concours provinciaux et nationaux. Il a une formation autodidacte en photographie. Malgré qu'il mène une carrière scientifique portant sur la santé des forêts, il réalise divers projets artistiques multidisciplinaires célébrant la beauté de la nature.
Ceux-ci intègrent ses interprétations au piano et sa photographie. Dans le projet Danse avec les arbres, il met à profit ses talents en captation vidéo par drone afin de magnifier la relation unique de chaque danseuse avec les arbres.

 

Alain Audet (musique et vidéo)

Alain étudie la guitare classique à l’École de musique de l’Université Laval. Après l’obtention d’un DEC en musique et d'une technique en audiovisuel, il poursuit un baccalauréat multidisciplinaire en création littéraire, culture musicale et réalisation audionumérique.

Il fonde la maison de production Nopal musique et réalise plusieurs projets et albums à compte d’auteur. Il étudie actuellement au baccalauréat en composition tout en vaquant à ses projets de création.

Tirage des récompenses

Les tirages auront lieu à la fin de la campagne de financement, soit à l'été 2018.

Présentation du projet

Il y aura un lancement de la vidéo à l'automne 2018 avec performance en direct (lieu et date à déterminer). Nous offrirons gracieusement aux organismes intéressés la possibilité d'utiliser cette vidéo comme outil de sensibilisation à la protection de la nature et aux arts.
story_txt: Christine Simard (conceptrice du projet et danse)Christine travaille dans le domaine des sciences naturelles depuis 28 ans, d'abord comme naturaliste interprète et assistante de recherche en écologie forestière. Parallèlement elle pratique la danse et expérimente diverses approches dans le mouvement. Le Buto, le contact improvisation, le flamenco et le tango argentin contribuent à la construction du langage qu’elle développe au gré de son inspiration. Christine travaille également au sein du Papillon blanc, danse; un organisme qui intervient auprès des personnes en perte d'autonomie.Passionnée de nature, cette dernière nourrit une grande partie de la production photographique qu’elle expose dans des organismes ou galeries de la région de Québec.​ Julia-Maude Cloutier (danse)Julia-Maude est interprète et chorégraphe en danse contemporaine. Elle pratique en parallèle des arts physiques tels la capoeira et l'art du déplacement (parkour). Sa recherche est ancrée dans le mouvement, ce que le corps athlète a comme possibilité créative. Au centre de ses préoccupations : l'être humain et les relations entre individus. Pour ce faire, elle préconise le travail in situ et multidisciplinaire. Maryse Damecour (danse, participation bénévole)Après des études en sociologie (université), Maryse complète le programme de l’École de danse de Québec. Depuis 2009, elle œuvre en danse, performance, musique et théâtre auprès d’artistes tels que Daniel Bélanger, Hanna Ab Del Nour, Laurence Brunelle-Côté et Kira Kirsch. Maryse poursuit la sincérité dans la danse. Elle cherche un geste complet, qui est sous tendu par une émotion, un état corporel, un regard, une attention, une intention, un désir. Elle appelle une danse motivée par les mouvements intérieurs et profonds tout en conscientisant la forme matériel du corps. Sa motivation artistique est la communication et la transmission. Alliant la danse, la performance, les arts visuels, la musique et la parole, Maryse adresse des thématiques sociales et humaines et vise à participer à la réflexion collective autant sociétale qu’artistique. Stéphanie Gaudreau (danse)Photo : Charles Bélisle - @belisle.proThérapeute par le mouvement, danseuse, pédagogue et femme de la terre, depuis 1996 elle dédie sa vie professionnelle à l’Être humain.Engagé activement depuis 1992 dans la communauté de Contact Improvisation, fondatrice de l’ACI à Montréal et de « Danse Orée des bois » situé dans la pleine nature de l’Estrie. Marie-Noëlle Goy (danse)Après des études professionnelles en danse contemporaine et classique en France, Marie-Noëlle Goy soucieuse d'approfondir sa démarche artistique s’est également formée à l’animation culturelle, au théâtre, à la création et l’animation de projets artistiques et culturels. En 1994, elle va s'investir dans la fondation du centre culturel et artistique le Café des Arts de Québec.Danseuse, comédienne et metteure en scène, tour à tour, c'est la passion pour l'être humain vulnérable et fragilisé par la maladie qui va la pousser à plonger dans un projet novateur de danse à l’hôpital en cofondant Le Papillon blanc, danse (OBNL) en 2013.Sa démarche est soutenue par un élan intérieur de beauté, de vérité et de vitalité qui articule sa danse et sa présence vers l'harmonie et le bien-être. Elle crée ainsi des visites dansées et des médiations culturelles dans les CHSLD, CRDI, Hôpitaux et centres de cancérologie du Québec. ​Andrée Levesque-Sioui (chant)Andrée est Wendat de la communauté de Wendake près de Québec, sa ville natale. Auteure mélodiste interprète, elle affectionne particulièrement les possibilités qu’offrent l’improvisation et les jeux rythmiques de sa tradition orale. La voix devient, cet instrument de quête d’oralité enfouie, l’éveil d’une mémoire par le chant, la langue et les tambours. Au-delà du style musical, c’est l’authenticité de la démarche humaine au cœur de l’expérience vocale qui l’interpelle. Chaque style lui permet d’explorer certains aspects de sa personnalité et l’ouvre à de nouveaux espaces.En suivant diverses formations, elle a exploré le chant classique et gospel, le yoga du son, le chant choral, Estill voice training et le théâtre. Innucadie 2017, Gala prix du gouverneur général 2017, Ensemble nous sommes Québec, Kiugwe, Jeux para-panaméricains 2015, WendaKébec, Bruits du monde, Kwahiatonhk, murmures et torrents de la grande tortue, Les 4 directions, Libérons les voix etc. Elle est l’interprète principale de trois albums: Yahndawa’ (2011), (meilleure réalisation d’album aux Native American Music Awards 2013 et meilleure musique du monde aux Eworld Music Award 2012); Fais dodo mon trésor (2012) et Ozalik (2013). Elle a chanté sur la chaîne APTN pour l’émission TAM. Engagée dans sa communauté, elle y enseigne la langue wendat auprès des jeunes et des adultes depuis 2010.   Jean Désy (poésie)Jean est né au Saguenay. Il enseigne à l’Université Laval à Québec, en médecine et en littérature. Il pratique toujours la médecine en tant que dépanneur dans le pays cri de la Baie-James et au Nunavik. Parmi ses dernières parutions, un recueil de récits d’inspiration médicale intitulé L’accoucheur en cuissardes, publié aux éditons XYZ en avril 2015; un recueil de poésie en collaboration avec Normand Génois et intitulé Bras-du-Nord, en septembre 2015, aux éditions Mémoire d’encrier; un court essai sur le métissage et la métisserie, paru en septembre 2016 chez Mémoire d’encrier, intitulé Amériquoisie; un essai portant sur la spiritualité, paru en mars 2017 chez XYZ éditeur, en collaboration avec Isabelle Duval André Beaudoin (vidéo drone)André est passionné de nature, de musique et de photographie depuis toujours. En particulier, il a une solide formation en piano classique acquise à l'École Vincent d'Indy de Montréal et il a décroché quelques prix dans des concours provinciaux et nationaux. Il a une formation autodidacte en photographie. Malgré qu'il mène une carrière scientifique portant sur la santé des forêts, il réalise divers projets artistiques multidisciplinaires célébrant la beauté de la nature.Ceux-ci intègrent ses interprétations au piano et sa photographie. Dans le projet Danse avec les arbres, il met à profit ses talents en captation vidéo par drone afin de magnifier la relation unique de chaque danseuse avec les arbres. Alain Audet (musique et vidéo)Alain étudie la guitare classique à l’École de musique de l’Université Laval. Après l’obtention d’un DEC en musique et d'une technique en audiovisuel, il poursuit un baccalauréat multidisciplinaire en création littéraire, culture musicale et réalisation audionumérique.Il fonde la maison de production Nopal musique et réalise plusieurs projets et albums à compte d’auteur. Il étudie actuellement au baccalauréat en composition tout en vaquant à ses projets de création.Tirage des récompensesLes tirages auront lieu à la fin de la campagne de financement, soit à l'été 2018.Présentation du projetIl y aura un lancement de la vidéo à l'automne 2018 avec performance en direct (lieu et date à déterminer). Nous offrirons gracieusement aux organismes intéressés la possibilité d'utiliser cette vidéo comme outil de sensibilisation à la protection de la nature et aux arts.

story:
BETA SPACES 2010

The fourth annual BETA Spaces (Bushwick Exhibition Triangle of Alternative Spaces), produced by Arts In Bushwick, will be held on November 14, 2010 in our Brooklyn neighborhood.

BETA Spaces is a COMPLETELY FREE one-day festival of conceptualized and thematic group exhibitions, in which curators are given an opportunity to re-imagine non-traditional exhibition spaces to present innovative contexts for artwork. The festival takes place roughly within a twenty square block area of Bushwick and East Williamsburg. BETA Spaces 2010 will feature over 50 collaborative exhibitions, including the work of roughly 300 artists! Visit our Gallery tab to download a PDF of the program, with a map and full list of shows!

The money raised on IndieGoGo will cover printing, administrative and insurance costs. All contributions are tax-deductible through our fiscal sponsor, Fractured Atlas.

Check out our VIP perks listed on the right!

Arts in Bushwick is an all-volunteer organization; our mission is to promote & support local artists, serve the community at large through arts education & creative accessibility & organize all residents & stakeholders in Bushwick to fight development-driven displacement & work toward an integrated, sustainable community.

For more information on BETA Spaces and Arts in Bushwick, please visit our website at artsinbushwick.org

story:
Welcome

The BA (Hons) Photography graduate show from Blackpool & The Fylde College will introduce you to the Northwest’s freshest photographic talent. This IndieGoGo campaign is a fund-raising initiative organised by the graduating class of 2011, to help us raise money to take our graduate exhibition to Cube Gallery in Manchester and the AOP Gallery in London.


What we need

Our overall target to raise is £5000 (roughly $8100). Through various other means of fund-raising we have £1900 already in the kitty, which leaves £3100 ($5000) still to raise. This is where you come in...


How you can help

We are asking for a £10 ($15) donation, and in return we will give each donor an A4 signed photographic print (from a choice of three), for a donation of £25 ($40), each donor will receive all three A4 prints, and for a donation of £50, each donor will receive all three A4 prints, and a signed A3 print of anything in the exhibition.


We completely understand if you aren’t in a position to donate, financially it’s a tough time for everyone. Please remember that you can still help and make a huge difference by spreading the word to everyone you know.

story:
NEW INCENTIVES FOR JANUARY!

Hello all! I've decided to sweeten my deal by doing some non-caricature work exclusively available for the duration of this campaign.

The first print is the print of my octopus ladies, or Cecaelia. Because few things say "I'm an artist" like combining tasteful nudity with tentacles.

If the above image looks a little squished, try right clicking and opening it in a new tab or window. I assure you the print is not squished.

The second print I'm offering is a popular work I did featuring a clash of a number of popular video game characters.

 

 

The last print is a promotional poster for one of the webcomics I'm writing, and the one I have the story the most developed for. Its called The Marvelous Metahumans of Metroit, and actually started out as a D&D-styles game with some of my buddies. This comic was born from some of our game sessions and story ideas, with my personal twist on story telling (which involves including "everything awesome" and making it work.) I'm super excited to get started drawing the issues of this comic, and I'm hoping it'll be on a brand new Cintiq!

Thank you all for all your continued support. I have never felt quit as loved and awesome as I have this last month.

 

Who is this kid?

Hello and welcome to my little fund raiser. My name is Jared Stokes and I've spent the last three years cutting my teeth as a caricature artist at Busch Gardens. In that time I've developed a pretty unique style which I call "getting Stoked!"

However, I've hit a bit of a snag in the road. Normally, the money I make doing caricatures is fine. It's nothing to retire on, but it gets me through. However, this last summer the weather was terrible, which affected our sales, our hours, and our pay. I blew through $3,000 I had in savings to make rent and pay my student loan bills, and business at the park just never picked back up. I had to move back in with my parents - where I'm very grateful - but I share a tiny bedroom with my girlfriend and next to zero space to work on artwork. I've been searching for another job with no success and morale is running out.


Which is where this comes in. If I'm ever going to take a career risk this is the time to do it - when I'm living with my parents and have very little to lose. I want to get established in the realm of digital art. I've written two webcomics and thought of tons of clever t-shirt designs and have gotten increasing interest in my freelancing capabilities - and I need a suitable piece of equipment to work on.  My Wacom tablet and laptop are starting to show their age. I want a Cintiq.


I'm offering caricatures to raise the money. I have developed a very unique style over the years and really enjoy seeing where my craft is developing. I'm getting petty stoked about this project and I hope you'll get Stoked, too!

 

What's in it for me?

Good feelings and cool art of you, your friend, your kids, your dogs, whoever you think needs a good Stoking.
 
If you give me just 1$ you'll have my eternal and sincerest thanks.
 
***IMPORTANT*** For the following rewards, please leave either an email in the comment box when you make your contribution, or send me a message on my facebook fanpage https://www.facebook.com/JaredDraws so that we can discuss reference photos and subject matter for your drawings. THANKS!
 
If you donate 10$ I'll give you a neat digital sketch of yourself like this!

 

At 25$, I'll give you a totally Stoked marker and watercolor caricature like this!

 

For 35$, I'll not only Stoke you, but a friend or significant other as well!

-OR- I'll draw you as your favorite super hero, video game character, sports star, or riding a glorious Rhinoceros across the Bifrost Rainbow Bridge into Asgard. NOTHING is off limits! Go wild!

 

Finally, if you're feeling SUPER GENEROUS, if you donate 100$ to my cause I will PAINT a caricature of you or a friend on a blank sketchbook to take with you wherever you go! I'll even tag the sketchbook with a doodle page!

 

 

What will this accomplish?

Like I said, I'm trying to look to bigger and better things in my art career. I want to design t-shirts and draw webcomics and (hopefully) make money doing it. You will be helping me upgrade my current and aging technology and prepare myself for the jump into the digital art world. You will be helping to put more art into the world and that has never, ever been a bad idea.

What if I'm broke?

That's okay! So am I!
But you can still help out. Tell a friend, no, tell seven friends, your family, write it on a bathroom stall, tweet it, tumbl it and put it on facebook. Spreading the word can help me out just as much as a monetary contribution!
 
Thanks for looking at my project page!

story:
What are we Building?

Your donations will help us convert this old airport baggage truck...

... into Santa Claus's Rocket Sleigh: The Merry Marauder!

 

Why a Rocket Sleigh?

Everyone loves getting gifts! Everyone loves Holiday cheer! Everyone loves Santa! The Merry Marauder will be an ideal base for interactive mischief and gifting. Planned playa gifts include ice deliveries, deep playa art tours, ice cold towels, the Santafication of others, and much general jolly mayhem!

Why We Need Your Help

You know why you never hear much about East Coast mutant vehicles? Because they are a pain in the ass! It’s a ton of work to modify an old beat up vehicle into something beautiful. You need somewhere to build it, a way to transport it across country and back, and somewhere to store it when your're done. All of this is very expensive in terms of time, tools, and money.

So why build an art car?

The truth is, there is no good reason. It's art! We are doing it for it’s own sake – because it’s fun! The team building the Merry Marauder has been attending Burning Man since 1998, and running Santarchy in Washington DC since 2001. Building the Merry Marauder is something we’ve never done before – a whole new set of challenges to overcome and problems to solve. We have artists from San Fran working on the design, from Raleigh building the reindeer, from Philly building the sleigh runners, and a crew of gear heads in DC keeping the car running and doing all the assembly.

Where is the money going?

  • Fabrication: Piles of new wood, stainless steel sleigh runners, and many repurposed vintage parts.
  • Sound: Santa's sleigh will be powered by stereo rocket pods playing your favorite holiday tunes.
  • Rudolph: Our steampunk reindeer will pack a 500w halogen search light nose (photos soon!).
  • Color changing LED Lighting
  • Power: The Merry Marauder is a 48v electric vehicle. Harnessing the batteries to run all these lights and toys requires some tricky engineering.
  • Upholstery: The Marauder will be a comfy ride for all guest Santas.
  • Transport: Washington DC to Black Rock City NV, and back.

SWAG/PERKS:

In gratitude for your donations we are offering some of the best SWAG around:

Santarchy and Safety Third Patches:

Merry Marauder Necklace:

Personalized Vintage Marauder Survival Canteen/Cup:

Note: All swag will be sent out in early August, but if you want it earlier, drop us an email at santa@merrymarauder.com and we'll see what we can do!

How Else You Can Help?

We could also use your help BUILDING the Marauder! Like the Merry Marauder page on Facebook to find out about build days, painting, and neighborhood test drives. You can also follow construction progress at www.merrymarauder.com.

story:
Our Story

We've created this project to help support the funding of a mural painting to honor Father Richard Purcell and his work sheltering homeless people with AIDS in San Francisco.  I joined this project as a videographer to support my friend, mural artist Laura Campos, in fulfilling one of Richard's last requests before he died. 


The Impact

Father Richard's legacy will live on in his foundations, and in this mural honoring his creative spirit and deep compassion for the homeless, the sick, the rejected.


What We Need & What You Get

We are trying to collect the money to be able to pay for art supplies, paint, brushes, and mural protective coats and also time that the artist needs to paint this project 4 to 8 weeks. Part of the money will also go to get silkscreens for the artist to make special one of a kind T-shirts and posters, signed by the artist.


Other Ways You Can Help

Please get the word out and make some noise about our campaign. Don't forget about the share tools!

The Impact
Father Richard's legacy will live on in his foundations, and in this 
mural honoring his creative spirit and deep compassion for the homeless,
 the sick, the rejected.


What We Need & What You Get
We are trying to collect the money to be able to pay for art supplies, 
paint, brushes, and mural protective coats and also time that the artist
 needs to paint this project 4 to 8 weeks.  Part of the money will also 
go to get silkscreens for the artist to make special one of a kind 
T-shirts and posters, signed by the artist.


Other Ways You Can Help
Please get the word out and make some noise about our campaign. Don't forget about the share tools!

story:
My name is James Harmon. I'm a 28 year old man, and I've been making music and writing books for the better part of five years now ... and, honestly, I couldn't be happier. I can't say that I'm making a decent living, partly due to the fact that I have a habit of (or I at least try) giving away most of the work I create, for little to no profit. I've met some very generous people in my life that have always helped me through tough times, and because of them, I'm a big believer in volunteering, giving back to the local community, and maintaining a simple lifestyle. Over the past year, I've had serious discomfort in my abdomen, which has made it very difficult to maintain my simple lifestyle. Besides being more fatigued than usual, I've lost about 80 pounds due to feelings of premature satiety brought on by bloating and discomfort. It's gotten to the point that I'm rarely able to actually eat any of my baked creations. It's not a total loss though, because through baking I am able to donate my creations to shelters. I have been trying to go to see the doctor for the past year or so, but unfortunately I don't qualify for most of the state run medical programs I've tried to apply for ...


I'm obviously not qualified to come to any conclusions concerning any ailments I may or may not have. While I feel that whatever is going on doesn't appear life threatening (given the fact that I'm still living), between the constipation, abdominal swelling, and rare (but throbbing) pain I do feel it requires medical attention; which means I really need to get my ass in to see a doctor, pronto. I am unable at this time to pay for anything medical related. If I can get simple medical attention to see if there's a blockage I can relieve, or if godzilla forbid it's something more life threatening like a tumor or an enlarged organ, I can go forward knowing without walking into the unknown, wasting time and money.


Any amount of money you contribute would be ... greatly appreciated. You're a wonderful human being for even making it this far, and I honestly wouldn't know what to do without all of you. Look to the right and you'll see some options for contributing; you'll notice that one of the options includes receiving baked goods.


Seriously though, thank you for your time.


http://www.facebook.com/pages/James-Harmon/62064412336

story:
What is your relationship with plants?

Caroline Caswell and Ethan Tate are two artists from Michigan who like plants. 

The Plant Encounters project is an independently-driven roaming residency that seeks to activate and complicate our relationship with plants and plant’s relationship with us. The project will take many forms over the course of a 3+ month road trip throughout the western U.S. We will be visiting gardens, oceans, artists, homesteads, established residencies, and everywhere/everyone in between. Our travels are an exchange. While encountering the plant environments of various new places we have the opportunity and responsibility to offer views into the plant environments, both tangible and abstract, of our own homelands.  Encounters along the way will take the form of tiny collaborations… with artists, with plants, with everyday people we come across. A thirty-second dance performance with a nasturtium flower on the edge of California. A three hour interview with a life-long farmer. The opportunities are endless. 


One big focus of the project will be conducting video interviews to learn plant stories. We'll do this with people we meet as well as a more abstract form with plants we meet. We'll also complete short photo series, off-the-cuff installations and performances, and fibers pieces. Documentation of these mini-projects will be edited and published into small zines. A book will be published at the end that compiles everything together. Most of the work will be collaborative in form and we'll seek out a variety of artists, gardeners, and others to work with.

We're leaving in mid-January and heading south to New Orleans first. We'll then scoot across the SW and spend half a month in Los Angeles. Then it's up the coast to the bay area and to a homestead in Sonoma County where we'll spend the month of March. In April we'll finish our jaunt up the west coast to Vancouver and then the plan is to circle back around for a residency in Iowa (provided we are accepted as residents). Here is the route:


Budget

We've budgeted out our trip and estimated that we'll need about $4000 to make this thing happen the best way that it can. Here's a breakdown of our budget:

  • gas (easily our biggest expense/we'll be moving a lot, $1225)
  • food budget ($850 at $50/week)
  • general supplies/clothing (art supplies/camping gear/toiletries, $300)
  • housing (camping fees/hotels when we're stuck in a snowstorm in west Texas in January, $400)
  • emergency (cars break down/people get sick/we also need to live somewhere after this thing is over, $1000)
  • residency fees ( if we are accepted into art residencies they cost money, $600 at $100 per person per week for 3 weeks)
We've saved about $2000 of our own so we're asking for help on the other half. If we are funded and have leftover money (from our emergency fund or if we don't get accepted into residencies) we'll use it for furthering the project through exhibition and publication. 

We'll be tracking our budget throughout the trip and all funders will receive a post-project summary of where our money went. 

Perks

Our perks borrow from our experiences in photography, publishing, fibers, cooking and performance. A few will be delivered pre-project but the majority of them will become integral aspects of the work we create for Plant Encounters. Our Snapchat updates, handmade postcards, zines, hankies, and photo prints will detail stories of people and plants we encounter along the way. The Plant Encounters book will combine all these stories into one finished project. Our premium perks offer our face-to-face services as plant-talkers, chefs, and performance planners. We're even giving away our own plants with the "house plant for you" perk!

^ hand-printed postcards!

You can check out each of our websites for examples of work we've done in the past and get an idea of how this new work will turn out: Ethan and Caroline.

The Impact

Plants have always been a large topic of conversation but our society's increasing interest in plant-based diets, local agriculture, and environmentalism has put them at the forefront of today's dialogues. We believe there is something lacking from these conversations. Plants are treated as scientific tools but we lack the empathy to truly relate to them. Plants are tender, living beings and should be viewed as such. The Plant Encounters project looks to activate our relationship with plants. We want to get down and dirty with plants. We want to hangout with them and talk with them like we would a friend or a lover. We believe this approach more appropriately honors plants for the role they play in our lives. We're also complicating our relationship with plants. By raising awareness of new ways to relate to plants, we are shifting our view of plants to be a more rich and complex one. 

These two goals of activating and complicating position our work as a new perspective in the conversation of plants and what they mean to us. We believe that what we have to offer can result in a more holistic approach to engaging with plants. And this intimate approach can only lead to a better understanding of how engagement with plants can better ourselves and others. 

Risks & Challenges

Given that our project revolves around traveling and interacting with people, there are a lot of risks at play. To us, the biggest risk is asking others to work with us. We will be entering other's spaces and inviting them to participate in our project. What's in it for them? While a good portion of our trip is pre-planned, we intend on visiting places where we know nobody and have no set-in-stone intention. In order to make our exchanges with others more equitable, we view ourselves as a database of plant-based stories and ideas. With each encounter, we listen and we pass the story of that encounter on to others. We have our own stories and we also exist as messengers for the stories of others. We understand this is a huge responsibility and we will strive to treat others and their stories with respect and dignity. We believe this mentality will allow us to have an incredibly enriching series of encounters with all the different people we meet.

The traveling aspect of the trip also lends itself to more straightforward risks. The main precaution we've taken is building $1000 of emergency funding into our budget. This makes up about a quarter of our entire budget and we'll surely need to  delve into it at some point. Aside from cash, Caroline has spent a good portion of her life traveling, including a 3-month road trip a few years ago. She has the experience of how to play it safe while traveling with your entire life in your trunk.

We also recognize that our project seeks to create a huge variety of works instead of focusing on one or two main mediums. As artists, we have purposefully strayed from putting ourselves into the boxes of a chief medium. We believe in the radical potential of experimentation and are consistently working with new mediums. This interdisciplinary approach is built into our artistic practice and, thus, will be a large part of Plant Encounters. Our movement between mediums will manifest in works that subvert norms and traditions and offer up fresh perspectives on plants.


Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot afford to contribute or simply do not want to, you can still help us by sharing this campaign across your social networks! Pass it along to friends who love plants or simply post about it on Facebook/Twitter/etc.

We'd also love to collaborate with you in some form! Please be in touch if you'd like to meet with us at any point on our journeys.

THANKS SO MUCH

story:
What is Drawlie?

Drawlie was created to help people start and improve their drawing skills by making the process friendlier and more accessible.

Our sketchbook combines exercises and guides together with blank pages, so you can practice and draw freehand. Always have it with you and be ready for when creativity strikes!

Simple & Fun

Learning to draw with Drawlie is easy, convenient and stress free. Lessons are designed not to take up too much time so that you can use every spare moment to sketch something on your own.

Drawlie is for those who have never drawn anything in their lives, as well as for those who have experience but want more.

You will find different styles and topics in your sketchbook, as various artists prepare different lessons.

Why drawing?

Let's face it - at some point in your life, the ability to draw would have come in so handy! 

Drawing is beautiful in addition to being useful; the ability to transfer your imagination onto paper is irreplaceable.  It helps you express your thoughts, makes you more creative and most of all, brings a lot of fun!

Who are we?
We are Zuzia & Michał - siblings who live in Warsaw, Poland. 

After graduating from business school, Michał worked in an advertising agency where he always wished he had the ability to draw, so that he could visualize his ideas better. Zuzia is a final-year painting student at the Academy of Fine Arts in Warsaw. She decided to help Michał learn to sketch by giving him her own sketchbook for inspiration. The idea to create DRAWLIE popped out right away!

What do we need money for?

We really need your support. We will allocate funds in:

  • finding more artists to create lessons - we already prepared most of them but we want Drawlie to be as good as possible
  • starting the production
  • inventory
  • company set up, store, website

story:
THE BOAT is located where the Tonlé Sap River meets the Mekong, right after the Japanese Bridge, from Phnom Penh city center. Originally built as a hotel, THE BOAT was abandoned three years ago. It is structurally sound but with an unfinished and fading interior. All it needs is a little love and care to activate it!

We want to create the most exciting and creative venue Phnom Penh has ever seen! A place where everyone can come to meet, drink and experience art in unexpected ways. A place where artists, dancers, musicians and filmmakers can create and showcase new work.  A place where everyone can discover something new.

We’re investing in ways to fund a viable and sustainable arts project, while staying focused on creativity.

THE BOAT is a social enterprise that will house restaurants, live event venues, offices for creative professionals, galleries, artist studios and a non-profit art center. ALL business activities will support a public art program of exhibitions, performances and provide important resources for artists, like studios and workshops. That means that whether you come for a party, to eat, or to join an art event, what you spend will support creativity!

Click here to discover more about the activities, floor by floor.

There are very few funding opportunities and spaces for artists in Cambodia and because of that Cambodian artists often exhibit and perform outside the country. THE BOAT will give them the space they deserve and need to work, meet other artists and share their ideas, here, at home, in Cambodia. Most importantly, it will offer a dynamic program and learning opportunities for the public. 

There will always be something happening on THE BOAT:

Diversity and creativity are at the heart of everything we will do. And we’re betting that when you put a DJ, a filmmaker and a classical Khmer dancer on a boat something exciting is going to happen. Something that attracts international visitors, international artists, making Phnom Penh a center of creativity in the region.

Click here to learn more about the Creative Hub, the heart and soul of the project.

We’ve been looking for somewhere big enough for years. A venue big enough to accommodate the dream of a contemporary art centre. THE BOAT is unlike any other space in Phnom Penh, offering generous space right in the capital and situated in a beautiful landscape at the confluence of one of the world’s most important waterways.

The Tonle Sap and Mekong rivers are an important part of Cambodia’s history, mythology and livelihood. We believe this will serve as inspiration for both artists and the public. 

Three years have passed since the construction has stopped and the boat is in variable conditions.  In some areas it is almost new while others have suffered damage from rain, sun and time! Some floors are very close to be operational, while others will require more renovation and additional construction.

For this early stage, our goal is $40,000! With this amount, we will be able to :

- enable access to the mooring site and parking: $15,000

- build the bridge to access the boat: $10,000

- renovate the elevator and add safety features on three floors: $15,000

If we reach the goal, PLUS an additional $15,000, we can :

- install electricity and water: $8,000

- acquire additional safety equipment: $2,000

- and launch the first art events for 6 months: $5,000

WHEN do we need it by?

Mid-January! Time is running and we have to start the renovation works before it gets worse and requires more time and money.

By purchasing one of the below perks, you'll directly contribute to the boat's renovation.  Art and fun for a good cause!

You can also simply donate a free amount, without perks, it will be highly appreciated! Click here to download our Terms & Conditions.

We are a group of entrepreneurs from different backgrounds that have invested personally in promoting art and culture in Cambodia. We are passionate about cultural growth and development of the country we have made our home. THE BOAT is an amazing opportunity that we believe will make Phnom Penh an exciting destination and provide important resources for artists and creatives.


Alexis De Suremain, Executive Director, Founding Partner - Founding Director of MAADS, Cambodia

Dana Langlois, Artistic Director, Founding Partner - Founding Director of JavaArts/Java Café 

Jeroen Van Daalen, Founding Partner - CEO Celliers d’Asie

THE BOAT is proud to be a project supported by UNESCO.

Press articles

The Phnom Penh Post | The Cambodia Daily | Khmer Times | Saigoneer

Join us.. !

Website | Facebook | Instagram | Twitter | Youtube | G+ | Google Maps

#SupportTheBoat

Show your support to the project by adding the hashtag #SupportTheBoat to your profile picture on social media! Help us spreading the word!

story:
Hello all,

SOUP invites you to become a part of creative projects.


Personal

My name is Ashton Bird and I am an installation artist and founder of SOUP experimental. In August of 2015, I moved from Vermillion, South Dakota to Tallahassee, Florida on scholarship in order to obtain my Masters in studio art through Florida State University.  The acceptance into the program and finally being in a critical environment was validating and gave me further confidence for pursuing creative goals that had been steeping.  Within months I began exploring Tallahassee for a building that may be suitable for exhibiting artwork, and in January stumbled across a warehouse apartment unit located in the RailRoad Square Art Park, Tallahassee. That month I signed the lease.  Within three weeks the warehouse became transformed into a three room experimental arts gallery.  A week following our fully functioning website launched.  Since the opening, SOUP is booked with monthly exhibitions and performances through until July 2017.  Much of my portfolio prior to graduate school was artist collaboration through installation, which evolved into artist collaboration through exhibition.

   * to all of the volunteers, help and mentors that supported SOUP through its initial construction, thank you so much!

About SOUP

SOUP is to become an established platform for emerging artists by offering not only exhibition space and opportunities, but also by actively championing our artists’ abilities with the intention of furthering their career.  SOUP’s gallery is both professional and flexible and allows emerging artists to experiment in an appropriate manner. SOUP’s idea of creation is not peculiar—but reaches to all creative modes of expression be it visual, performance, dance, music, design or poetry. 

SOUP also works to connect artists with other creative opportunities and aims to amplify Tallahassee’s presence in the national contemporary art dialogue through exhibiting MFA outreach exhibitions or artwork exchanges, networking to galleries, online promotion and overall acting as a base for career growth.  We are very lucky that our ideas have been well received with the recent showcasing of the University of Delaware, and the upcoming MFA exhibitions in Season 2 –the class of Georgia State University and two talented graduates from University of North Carolina at Greensboro.


*Kathleen Saunder's Subtropical 


Statement

“SOUP experimental showcases high-quality artworks made by the emerging artists from the surrounding area as well as provides a location to bring awareness of the contemporary creativity that Tallahassee emits.  Within our city, many artists explore a variety of different genre by blending beautiful concepts with physical medium.  This hybrid way of thinking cultivates our curiosities and continuously pushes our standard of exposition.  SOUP experimental wants to share the definition of contemporary art with the local, national and international community by offering rotating fine art exhibitions, artist performances, artists’ lectures, an online artist archive, traveling exhibitions and a yearly hard-copy review containing a documentation of the exhibiting artists from that year.  It is our objective to become distinct and transform Tallahassee into a noticeable new phenomenon.

Art’s definition is continuously changing—art is malleable and dynamic.  SOUP experimental seeks to become a platform for as much as possible and is fortunate enough to be a part of the unique, creative mind that exists solely in our neighborhood.”  

Founder and Director

Ashton Bird

SOUP experimental

What is SOUP’s creative projects?

Our creative projects are a way to provide exposure and experience for the artists exhibiting as well as make more art accessible to the public both on-location and digitally.

1. FANTASY

–SOUP’s first traveling exhibition hosted at the Metropolitan 250 Gallery in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. Five artists residing in Tallahassee, FL –including myself, have formed a loose collective and are collaborating to exhibit works together at several locations through-out the United States.  SOUP has applied to galleries with like-minded statements in hopes of bridging connections between our city and theirs.


Exhibiting in FANTASY:

Ashton Bird
:: ashtonbird.com
Sierra Kramer
:: sierrakramer.com
Mathew Lawrence
:: x-x-x-x-x-x-x.com
Chelsea Raflo
:: chelsearaflo.com
Lucia Riffel
:: luciariffel.com

   *We applied to 8 different calls on September 2nd and 3rd, we’ve heard back from 3 so far! *fingers crossed


2.  SOUP’s Season 1 annual

–SOUP’s annual is a hard-copy book that is designed to showcase the artists from the year’s exhibition schedule.  Each artist of Season 1 is displayed according to their exhibition’s month.  Within the front, a commemorative thank you page will be added for all the names that donated to our creative projects. Our campaign is not for purchasing a mass order of finished books, but allows us to order 3 to 5 printed proofs.  This ensures the quality of our item for both the patron and artists being represented.

3. SOUP mobile gallery app

–the SOUP mobile app is a mobile archive system that contains images of all the artwork having been shown within the confines of our space and allows the participant to interact with our collection and connect with previously shown artists.  Random high-quality images from our exhibition history are generated instantly with the participant able to swipe left or right.  Swiping left produces another artwork to appear while swiping right or liking, generates a new work, but places the liked art into a database that will showcase the most liked art.   The database will be available on our website and through the participant’s mobile device.  Each of the artwork’s images can be clicked on to have the artist’s information and portfolio link displayed as well.  We call this idea, “The Casual Archive of Contemporary Artwork”. The SOUP app opens accessibility to our gallery and actively participates with the public.  The SOUP application will be available for download via Play or App store.­


*Eric Mcneil performing live at ICON

Cost
*all names of donating patrons will be placed in a Thank You section located in the front of our Season 1 hardcopy

FANTASY at Metropolitan 250 located in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania.

Transportation|Delivery + Returning of work

- 4 trips
*cost is for roundtrip at 24mpg with price of gas at $2.45
* 1008 miles per trip

November 1 – 5 for installation and opening reception
 Trip 1
 Delivery to Philadelphia
 Trip 2
 Return to Tallahassee

November 28 - 30
 Trip 3
 Return to Philadelphia for de-install
 Trip 4
 Deliver work back to Tallahassee
     
- 1 vehicle

= $ 411.60
+ ~$200.00 for city miles and unexpected

Total:  $611.60



SOUP’s Season 1 Hardcopy

- SOUP is asking donors not for a large order of books, but to cover enough for at least 3 – 5 drafts.
*Custom order from blurb.com

Total: ~$300


SOUP mobile gallery app

Overview

SOUP Casual Archival of Contemporary Artwork will be a digital platform for users to consume and catalog information about artwork featured in the SOUP gallery. At its core, the platform being licensed will:

  • Display artwork and any associated information to users
  • Allow users to dismiss and save artwork to their personal catalog

 

To achieve these goals of the platform, the following will be developed:

  • Gallery Admin Portal
    • Web-based portal for gallery admins to upload and post new artwork and all associated metadata
    • The portal will create entries to the artwork database, which will populate in web and native apps
    • Gallery admins will also be able to edit and remove entries in the database, as well as retrieve stored usage data
  • Artwork Database
    • Storage for handling artwork and metadata retrieval, updating artwork popularity, user authentication, etc.
    • API endpoints for embedding data into gallery homepage
    • Google Firebase, a non-relation database, will be used
  • Web App Client
    • Dedicated website for SOUP app where users can interact with the application
    • HTML5 and other modern technologies will be used to create the web app client
    • Responisively developed to work on both desktop and mobile devices
  • iOS Native App
    • iOS native version of Web App Client converted using the Cordova framework
    • Submitted and listed in Apple AppStore
  • Android Native App
    • Android native version of Web App Client converted using the Cordova framework
    • Submitted and listed on Google Play



App is created from hired professional
Finished platform estimate to achieve all of the above
Total: ~$1500

------
Creative Project Total:

$2,411.60

SOUP is grateful for every donation at any amount. Help us reach our goal and expand our creative dialogue.

Sincerely,

SOUP

ps. Perks:
story_txt:
Hello all,SOUP invites you to become a part of creative projects.PersonalMy name is Ashton Bird and I am an installation artist and founder of SOUP experimental. In August of 2015, I moved from Vermillion, South Dakota to Tallahassee, Florida on scholarship in order to obtain my Masters in studio art through Florida State University.  The acceptance into the program and finally being in a critical environment was validating and gave me further confidence for pursuing creative goals that had been steeping.  Within months I began exploring Tallahassee for a building that may be suitable for exhibiting artwork, and in January stumbled across a warehouse apartment unit located in the RailRoad Square Art Park, Tallahassee. That month I signed the lease.  Within three weeks the warehouse became transformed into a three room experimental arts gallery.  A week following our fully functioning website launched.  Since the opening, SOUP is booked with monthly exhibitions and performances through until July 2017.  Much of my portfolio prior to graduate school was artist collaboration through installation, which evolved into artist collaboration through exhibition.   * to all of the volunteers, help and mentors that supported SOUP through its initial construction, thank you so much!About SOUPSOUP is to become an established platform for emerging artists by offering not only exhibition space and opportunities, but also by actively championing our artists’ abilities with the intention of furthering their career.  SOUP’s gallery is both professional and flexible and allows emerging artists to experiment in an appropriate manner. story:
GRiTT 3D is the only 3D-printed mouthguard made with our one-of-a-kind, medical-grade, softer filament. Our goal is to provide over 12 million community and college athletes with a custom mouthguard. 

Our mission and focus is to bring this product to market, to make such an important piece of sports equipment accessible, affordable and customizable. With your help, we can deliver a custom mouthguard for a fraction of the price. Your investment will help us decrease the cost of production and distribution to retail our product at $15.99!  

Why you should support our project:

  • We plan to offer the only multi-purpose 3D printed mouthguard on the market
  • Our mouthgurads will be made from a unique, pliable, medical-grade filament
  • Our mouthguard will be made from FDA approved materials
  • Gritt 3D is NHSA compliant
  • Our mouthguards will be 100% made in the USA
  • Every athlete deserves access to the benefits of custom protection

What your pledge will do: 

  • Help us to buy raw product in bulk to reduce operating costs 
  • Allow us to purchase industrial 3D printers
  • Support the development of retail and commercial packaging
  • Establish distribution relationships to get mouthguards to anyone, anywhere

After searching for a quality custom mouthguard it became apparent how truly inaccessable they are. Both the cost and dentist visits needed to get a custom guard puts the best guards out of reach for most families. GRiTT 3D will offer a solution. Our company combines innovation, quality, value and technology to create both a unique business opportunity and an amazing, affordable product.  Every GRiTT 3D mouthguard will be made from FDA-approved materials and is NHSA compliant.

CUSTOMIZABLE

We will have the only mouthguard able to be custom-designed according to an individual's age, dental impression, and sport. For example, we will be able to design a guard specifically for the unique facial structures in athletes as young as 8!  Our customizable features increase breathability, provide for improved communication, and maximum comfort. Each guard can also be personalized with team colors and logo and even an athlete’s name.

We can design for the snowboarder who needs extra protection at the bite impact points. Or we can design a mouthguard for the ice hockey player who needs reinforcement and protection for the front teeth.

NOT JUST FOR ATHLETES

GRiTT 3D can design a guard for the soldier in the military with added soft tissue coverage, greater breathability, and added protective features for stress or teeth grinding. 

OUR UNIQUE RIDGES

Each mouthguard features our patent-pending Ridges, which will provide every athlete with a secure, comfortable fit, optimal breathability, and protection during competition. Because of the property and shape of the Ridges, the guard is less bulky and will stay more securely on the teeth. 

FDA APPROVED MATERIAL?

Many parents have asked us, "Is this product safe for my child to wear for several hours?"  and the answer is "Yes!" 

Most of us believe that the mouthguards we buy for our kids at the store are FDA approved. The unfortunate truth is that most of them are not. The FDA dose not regulate mouthguards and thus does not approve or disapprove of any mouthguard products.  As many people of the GRiTT 3D Team are parents ourselves, we are adamant about a product that is affordable AND safe.  We are taking the unrequired step to use materials that have already been approved by the FDA for intraoral use.  At GRiTT 3D, we have chosen to use the very best and highest quality of FDA approved 3D print filament available to create our mouthguards, exclusively manufactured by a  Biometric Medical Laboratory. 

Our medical-grade, FDA-approved material is a blend of medical grade thermoplastics and is similar to the material used to make top quality custom mouthguards you might receive from a dentist. The difference in compounds is minimal but important to the unique 3D print process, without sacrificing shock absorption, comfort, or fit.  If you have further questions about the safety of our material, please do not hesitate to contact us at info[at]gritt3d[dot]com.

With continual advancements through research and field testing, our guard can provide unprecedented comfort, function, and style. We are proud to say we can develop a guard for anyone, anywhere. With your backing we hope to make this amazing product available for only $15.99!


GRiTT 3D PERK PRODUCTS:

$5 and Up - Sticker (4" x 1.5")

$23 and Up - T-shirt (Black or White)

story:
English:

For nine years, with the support of our entire community, puppeteers from throughout Latin America have been coming to Cochabamba to share their stories with Bolivian children.

Festititeres is a week-long festival for the propagation of puppetry in Bolivia, and an opportunity for puppet performers from different backgrounds to get to know each other and work together.

Until now, Festititeres has been funded by grassroots networks, and we intend to keep it that way. With just a few dollars each, among hundreds of people, we can keep the dream alive. Join the community with a small donation so that Festititeres can continue to be the most important puppet festival in Bolivia.

---

Español:

Desde hace nueve años, con el aporte de toda nuestra comunidad, han venido elencos internacionales a compartir sus historias con los niños bolivianos. 

El Festitíteres es un espacio para la difusión de los títeres en Bolivia y para el reencuentro e intercambio entre profesionales de este arte. También es una escuela, pues el intercambio profesional entre titiriteros es constante y enriquece nuestra visión. 

Hasta ahora hemos financiado este festival de forma independiente y queremos seguir así. Con pocos pesos cada uno, entre cientos de personas, podemos hacer este sueño realidad. Súmate al equipo con una pequeña contribución para que el Festitíteres siga siendo la fiesta más importante de los títeres en Bolivia.

---

Italiano:

Da nove anni, con l’appoggio della nostra comunità virtuale, sono venuti burattinai di tutto il mondo per compartire le loro storie con bambini boliviani.

Festiteres é uno spazio per la diffusione dei burattini in Bolivia, ed un opportunitá per burattinai di diversi paesi di incontrarsi e lavorare insieme.

Fin ora abbiamo finanziato questo festival in modo indipendente, e vogliamo continuare cosí. Se centinaia di persone contribuiscono qualche euro ciascuno, possiamo trasformare questo sogno in realtà. Entra a fare parte della nostra comunità con un piccolo contributo che permetterà a Festititeres di continuare ad essere il festival di burattini più importante della Bolivia.

---

Deutsch:

Seit neun Jahren und mit der Unterstützung unserer Community, sind
bereits elf Internationale Ensemble gekommen um ihre Geschichten mit
bolivianischen Kindern zu teilen

Das Festitíteres ist ein Raum, um Puppenspiel in Bolivien zu
verbreiten und ein Treffpunkt für Austausch unter Fachmenschen dieser Kunst.

Bis jetzt hat sich das Festitíteres unabhängig finanziert und wir
möchten dies auch so fortführen. Mit ein paar Euro pro Person,
zwischen hunderten von Menschen, können wir diesen Traum wahrwerden
lassen. Werde mit einem kleinen Beitrag Teil des Teams, so dass das
Festitíteres auch weiterhin das größte Fest der Puppen(spiele) in
Bolivien bleibt.

---
Français
Depuis neuf ans, avec le soutien de toute notre communauté, troupes internationales sont venues à partager leurs histoires avec les enfants boliviens.

Le "Festitíteres" est un espace pour la diffusion des marionnettes en Bolivie et pour la rencontre et l'échange entre les professionnels de cet art.

Jusqu'à présent, nous avons financé ce festival indépendamment et nous voulons que ça reste comme ça. Avec quelques "pesos" chacun, entre des centaines de personnes, nous pouvons faire que ce rêve se réalise. Rejoignez l'équipe avec une petite contribution pour assurer que "Festitíteres" reste le plus important festival de la marionnette en Bolivie.

story:
50 Women: A Celebration of Women's Contribution to Ceramics, Part Two

Two nationally known artists, Alex Kraft, Anthony Merino, and artist/media consultant, Melanie Shaw, are organizing an exhibition to celebrate the contributions of women working in ceramics today. Alexandra and Anthony are dedicated and recognized ceramic artists and supporters of the arts. We're continuing this campaign in order to raise the full amount needed, mainly for shipping and insuring the amazing artwork for this exhibition.

From historical figures like Méret Oppenheim, Beatrice Wood and Toshiko Takaezu, to many of the accomplished artists working today, women have made huge contributions in the field of ceramics.  This exhibition is organized to celebrate a cross section of contemporary female ceramic artists. The 50W exhibition is designed to be comprehensive and will include tile, installation, sculpture, figurative, and functional ceramics. While many of the artists will be internationally acclaimed, others will still be in graduate school or unknown in the larger ceramic community.  

50 Women will be one of the first female only exhibition of ceramics in the United States and will promote the discourse of female contributions to the arts on this very special occasion. The exhibition will coincide with the 50th Anniversary of National Council on Education for the Ceramic Arts' (NCECA) yearly conference. Contributors will ensure that this exhibition takes place and hopefully will inspire other major institutions to follow suit. The 50W team is currently submitting an exhibition proposal to NCECA in order for this show to be accepted as part of the official 50th Anniversary event. 

Funding Specifics

The monies raised in this campaign will fulfill the following objectives:
  • Artwork Shipping/Insurance-Monies will be dedicated for round trip shipping and insurance for all artworks in the exhibition. 
  • Artwork Perks Shipping/Insurance-Monies to be dedicated to shipping and insuring the amazing Perks to be sent to you, the amazing supporters of this endeavor
  • Facility Rental-Monies dedicated to facility rental (if NCECA proposal is not accepted), insurance and additional personnel as needed for this event
Approximately 70-75% of the funds needed will be utilized for shipping alone. All monies raised that exceed the above requirements will be donated to a local Kansas City women's association.

50W Impact

We hope that women will respond to the 50W exhibition and corresponding Facebook group to see women who are empowered by the choice to be artists and be inspired to make any career choices they desire. Mrs. Kraft currently teaches at the University of North Georgia and brings several years of exhibition management to the project. Mr. Merino has published over 100 reviews and has curated 8 exhibitions. Their combined exhibition experience and didactical ideals will insure the contributors and spectators with an expansive look at contemporary female art and those that support this prototypical adventure.


Share and Support

Please donate to help make this vision come true. Feel free promote and share the 50W Indiegogo link with anyone you know who would like to help celebrate the work of women ceramic artists. Read and celebrate  women ceramic artists via our Facebook group page. Get the word out!

Facebook Group: 50 Women

We're continuing this campaign in order to raise the full amount needed, mainly for shipping and insuring the amazing artwork for this exhibition.

story:
Sponsor us for the MAK Games!

We are big fans of the MAK Center for Art and Architecture at the Schindler House. And as a result, we are excited to be able to compete in the 2015 MAK Games tennis tournament. The competition is a fundraiser for the MAK Center—they need us, and we need you.

We need a minimum of $500 to qualify for the draw, but we hope to raise a lot more!

If you help us compete for the MAK Cup, you’ll be supporting the ONLY art institution in the world that presents contemporary art and architecture programming while stewarding three landmarks of modern architecture by R.M. Schindler. 

Not to mention, your donation will give us the chance to compete on the stunning infinity tennis court at the Sheats/Goldstein Residence, a classic by architect John Lautner.

Any amount is welcome—no donation is too small! You will be thanked on the program and on the website, and at $100 and above, you’ll receive a MAK Center Friendship which ushers you into one of the most dynamic and interdisciplinary cultural institutions in Los Angeles.

  • All contributions are tax-deductible to the extent of the law.

story:
WHO ARE WE?

The Nerve Tank is a world-class innovator in theatrical performance. Founded by Melanie S. Armer and Chance Muehleck, the company collaborates with actors and designers in a spirit of artistic adventure and remodels traditional performance methods. We combine elements of popular culture, mediated image, and physical presence to test lines of engagement between spectator and live event.

Based in New York, we have staged works at chashama, FringeNYC, Dixon Place, University Settlement, Incubator Arts Project, the World Financial Center Winter Garden, and Pittsburgh’s Flux Festival. From 2008 to 2010 we were the resident theatre company of the Brooklyn Lyceum. In 2011, NT was named a Person of the Year by the New York Theatre Experience.

WHAT ARE WE DOING?

Glad you asked! We’re taking a big risk on an ambitious project. Inspired by the myth of Sisyphus, Glory Road is an interactive, outdoor performance featuring a 6 ½ foot metal sphere. As the sphere rotates, it triggers sound fragments via technology housed in its core. The performance will be presented by Arts Brookfield at New York’s Grace Building Plaza September 18 – 21. It’s free and open to the public.

Sisyphus was a daring and clever king who outwitted the gods on numerous occasions. He lied, stole, and murdered for fun and profit. He was also a brilliant navigator and inventor whose knowledge surpassed mortal limits. Zeus, affronted by his insolence, sentenced him to an absurd fate: Overseen by Persephone, Queen of the Underworld, Sisyphus must forever push a boulder up a mountain only to have it roll back down.

We’re using this myth to explore questions of futility, enslavement, and self-realization. Sisyphus’ overreaching exacts a terrible price, but one which he willingly pays. He views his endless torment as a kind of victory in that Zeus was so afflicted by his cunning he assigned Sisyphus a unique punishment, equal in scope and ambition to his mortal offences. The anti-hero relishes his stubborn pride. He’s a superstar of his own making.

As a company, we’re always looking to build work that challenges expectations and speaks directly to our accelerated, media-savvy culture. Glory Road is a project that marries several different worlds: Theatre, dance, contemporary art, large-scale installation, and cutting-edge digital technology. We think it’s the place performance needs to be moving, and we invite you to take the journey with us!

WHERE ARE WE AT?

The Nerve Tank has a proven track record of collaborating with designers and technicians in surprising ways and attracting audiences of varied interests and backgrounds. Our interactive installation The Attendants was presented by Arts Brookfield in 2011 to great acclaim; it was viewed worldwide via webcam, and the Village Voice called it “an important new development in performance.”

Glory Road’s main attraction, the giant sphere housing a 12-speaker array and specialized technology, is already built. We spent a long and rewarding week at The Wurks in Providence, RI welding, grinding, and bending metal to achieve a remarkable piece of kinetic sculpture. A record-breaking heat wave was no match for our intrepid fabricators.

The sphere has just been galvanized and is ready to come to New York and begin rehearsals. Our director, Melanie S. Armer, has been busy choreographing movement for Persephone and her “Minions,” and digital interface wizards Stephan Moore and Mikhail Mansion are programming sound files to respond to the sphere’s position in space as it’s pushed along the Plaza.

Costume designer Miodrag Guberinic is making a collection of beautiful, haunting pieces for our performers to wear, including an elaborate “lava dress” for Persephone (Robin Kurtz) and several jumpsuits embedded with QR codes for our faceless Minions. Video designer Chris Jordan is collaborating with co-founders Chance and Melanie to create content for the CRT screens.

WHAT DO WE NEED? WHAT DO YOU GET?

In short, we need $11,000 to offset the costs of producing Glory Road the way it—and our audience—deserve. Arts Brookfield has given us the start we need. Now, we look to you to help us create a truly memorable and groundbreaking experience.

The amount we’re asking for can be broken into three categories: Artist fees, materials, and transport. We believe in paying our performers and designers a competitive wage, so a fair chunk of our fiscal goal will be allocated to them. A significant amount will go to the purchase of large-scale set pieces such as CRT screens* and a hefty amount of red carpet. The remaining dollars will cover transportation expenses (a 600-pound, 6 ½’ steel sphere doesn’t move itself!).

Glory Road is free and open to the public. Which means we won’t be making any money with ticket sales. This is as it should be, but it’s imperative that we manage our budget with the resources we have. These resources include you, dear reader. Think of your donation as another kind of ticket to our grand spectacle.

And perks! Ah, the perks. For $25 you’ll get our company-sourced Recipes for Disaster: 13 Dishes to Get You Up and See You Through. For $50, add our all-cotton, super-swank Nerve Tank t-shirt. Want to learn to weld? How about computer coding? Jump up to $500 and receive personal, one-on-one coaching from our company members in a variety of disciplines. And for $1,000 we'll take you behind the scenes with our very special Truth or Dare perk.

WHAT ELSE CAN YOU DO?

Share this campaign freely and often. Visit our Facebook Page and become a fan. Get on our mailing list. And let us know if you think there’s a particular group or individual who might value our work in a meaningful way.

Crowdfunding can indeed seem like a Sisyphean task (yes, we went there). But with the support of our community we’re confident we’ll meet our goal.

WHERE CAN YOU SEE IT?

GLORY ROAD
An Arts Brookfield Commission

September 18 - 21, 2013
12 - 1:30pm & 4 - 6pm
(20-minute performances on loop)

Grace Building Plaza
1114 Avenue of the Americas (at 43rd Street)
New York City

Free and open to the public

Conception: Chance D. Muehleck
Director and Scenarist: Melanie S. Armer
Digital Interface Designers: Stephan Moore and Mikhail Mansion
Sound Design and Music: Stephan Moore
Lyrics: Chance D. Muehleck
Costume Designer: Miodrag Guberinic
Video Designer: Chris Jordan
Performers: Bizzy Barefoot, Stacia French, Ines Garcia, Jason Howard, Robin Kurtz, Mark Lindberg, Taylor Morrison, James “Face” Yu
Sphere Fabrication: Eric Coolidge
with assistance by Melanie S. Armer and Chance D. Muehleck
Sphere fabricated in residence at The Wurks, Providence, RI
Sphere Galvanization: V&S Galvanizing, Taunton, MA

*The Cathode Ray Tube is basically your charming old television set before it was replaced by flat screen technology.
